﻿CODE OF ORDINANCES CITY OF DORAVILLE, GEORGIA ____________ Published in 1992 by Order of the City Council Republished in 2010 ____________
OFFICIALS of the CITY OF DORAVILLE, GEORGIA AT THE TIME OF THIS REPUBLICATION ____________ Ray Jenkins Mayor ____________ Donna Pittman Councilmember and Mayor Pro Tem ____________ Murray Weed City Attorney ____________ Rhonda Blackmon City Clerk ____________ Pam Fleming Rob Roche Brian Bates Bob Spangler Maria Alexander City Council ____________ CURRENT OFFICIALS of the CITY OF DORAVILLE, GEORGIA ____________ Donna Pittman Mayor ____________ Robert Patrick Councilmember and Mayor Pro Tem ____________ Shawn Gillen City Manager ____________ Cecil McLendon Jr. City Attorney ____________ Sherry D. Henderson City Clerk ____________ Karina Reyna Deputy Clerk ____________ Pam Fleming Shannon Hillard M.D. Naser Dawn O'Connor Robert Patrick Sharon Spangler City Council PREFACE

PREFACE This Republication constitutes a complete republication of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Doraville, Georgia. Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1969 Code, as supplemented through July 9, 1969, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the city council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1969 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. Numbering System The numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of Chapter 1 is numbered 1-2 and the first section of Chapter 4 is 4-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter and at the same time new sections or even whole chapters can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 3-1 and 3-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 3-1.5. New chapters may be included in the same manner. If the new material is to be included between Chapters 12 and 13, it will be designated as Chapter 12.5. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. Indices The indices have been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the indexes themselves which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. Looseleaf Supplements A special feature of this republication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the republication. With this system, the republication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited and the appropriate page or pages affected will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the republication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. Keeping this republication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the republication. As revised sheets are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. Acknowledgments This republication was under the direct supervision of Eric Grant, Vice President, and Katrina Hansen, Supplement Editor, of the editorial staff of Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. The publisher is most grateful to Mr. Murray Weed, City Attorney, and Ms. Rhonda Blackmon, City Clerk, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this republication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs.
SUPPLEMENT HISTORY TABLE The table below allows users of this Code to quickly and accurately determine what ordinances have been considered for codification in each supplement. Ordinances that are of a general and permanent nature are codified in the Code Book and are considered "Includes." Ordinances that are not of a general and permanent nature are not codified in the Code Book and are considered "Omits." In addition, by adding to this table with each supplement, users of this Code of Ordinances will be able to gain a more complete picture of the Code's historical evolution.
PART I - CHARTER[1]

div.head: Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipal home rule, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 2; O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq.; exemplification of municipal minutes and other records, O.C.G.A. § 24-7-21; authority to adopt ordinances, resolutions or regulations, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-3.
Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, City of Doraville, Georgia," and may be so cited. (Code 1969, § 1-1) Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the Mayor and City Council: City. The words "the City" or "this City" shall be construed as if the words "of Doraville" followed it. City Council. The term "City Council" means the Mayor and Councilmen of the City of Doraville as provided in section 2.01 of the Charter. Computation of time. Except as otherwise provided by time period computations specifically applying to other laws, when a period of time measured in days, weeks, months, years, or other measurements of time except hours is prescribed for the exercise of any privilege or the discharge of any duty, the first day shall not be counted but the last day shall be counted; and, if the last day falls on Saturday or Sunday, the party having such privilege or duty shall have through the following Monday to exercise the privilege or to discharge the duty. When the last day prescribed for such action falls on a public and legal holiday as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 1-4-1, the party having the privilege or duty shall have through the next business day to exercise the privilege or to discharge the duty. When the period of time prescribed is less than seven (7) days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation. Corporation. Corporation shall include a limited liability company and other business entities. County. The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean the County of DeKalb. Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department of the City to do some act or make certain inspections it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or make the required inspection unless the terms of the provision or section designate otherwise. Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. Interpretation. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, such provision shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provision imposed by the Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three (3) or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. Keeper and proprietor. The words "keeper" and "proprietor" shall mean and include the persons, firms, associations, corporations, clubs and partnerships, whether acting by themselves or through a servant, agent or employee. Limits, corporation, City. The words "limits," "corporation" or "City" shall mean the corporate limits of the City, the legal boundary of the City of Doraville. Mayor. Whenever the word "Mayor" is used it shall mean the person duly elected as Mayor of the City of Doraville as provided in the Charter of the City. Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. Municipal court judge. The term "municipal court judge" means the judge of the municipal court as authorized in section 3.02 of the Charter, the assistant municipal court judge or any person appointed by the City Council to act as the municipal court judge. Charter reference— Municipal courts, art. III. Name of officer. Whenever the name of an officer is given it shall be construed as though the words "of the City of Doraville" were added. Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language; but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. Number. Words used in the singular include the plural and the plural includes the singular number. Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." Or, and. "Or" may be read "and" and "and" may be read "or" if the sense requires it. Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. Person. The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. Personal property. The term "personal property" shall include every species of property except real property, as herein described. Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" shall mean next before and next after, respectively. Premises. Whenever the word "premises" is used it shall mean place or places. Property. The word "property" shall include real and personal property. Public place. The term "public place" shall mean any park, cemetery, school yard or open space adjacent thereto, or any area available and/or accessible to the public, regardless of whether privately or municipally owned. Real property. The term "real property" shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments. Residence. The term "residence" shall be construed to mean the place adopted by a person as his place of habitation, and to which, whenever he is absent, he has the intention of returning. When a person eats at one (1) place and sleeps at another, the place where such person sleeps shall be deemed his residence. Seal. The word "seal" shall mean the City seal, the seal of the corporation. Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. Signature or subscription. The "signature" or "subscription" of a person shall include a mark when the person cannot write. State. The words "the state" shall be construed to mean the State of Georgia. Street. The word "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public highways in the City. Tenant, occupant. The words "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, shall include any person holding a written or oral lease or who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. Time. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. Week. The word "week" shall be construed to mean seven (7) days. Written or in writing. The terms "written" or "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. (Code 1969, § 1-2; Ord. No. 06-20, § 1, 7-10-06) State Law reference— Computation of time, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1; construction of definitions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-2; meaning of certain words, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3; time, O.C.G.A. § 9-11-6. Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections; history notes and references. (a) The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections nor as any part of the section nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. (b) The history notes appearing in parentheses after each section and the references and editor's notes scattered throughout the Code are for the benefit of the user of the Code and shall have no legal effect. (Code 1969, § 1-3) State Law reference— Notes and catchlines of code sections not part of law, O.C.G.A. § 1-1-7. Sec. 1-4. - Construction of ordinances. The same rules shall be applied in construing ordinances of this City as are applied in construing the statutes of this state, which rules are found in O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1, and the same meanings are to be given words found in the ordinances as are given similar words found in the statutes of this state. (Code 1969, § 1-4) Sec. 1-5. - Ordinances not affected by Code. Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following: (1) Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. (2) Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the City or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the City or any evidence of the City's indebtedness. (3) Any contract or obligation assumed by the City. (4) Any ordinance fixing the salary of any City officer or employee. (5) Any right or franchise granted by the City. (6) Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, widening, paving, etc., any street or public way in the City. (7) Any appropriation ordinance. (8) Any ordinance which, by its own terms, is effective for a stated or limited term. (9) Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor. (10) Any zoning ordinance. (11) Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any subdivision plat. (12) Any ordinance describing or altering the boundaries of the City. (13) The administrative ordinances or resolutions of the City not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this Code. (14) Any ordinance levying or imposing taxes not included herein. (15) Any ordinance establishing or prescribing street grades in the City. No such ordinance shall be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance which is repealed by this chapter. All such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length herein. Sec. 1-6. - Provisions considered continuations of existing ordinances. The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as ordinances adopted prior to this Code and included in such Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. Sec. 1-7. - Effective date of ordinances. Ordinances which do not provide for their taking effect at a different time shall take effect immediately after their passage. (Code 1969, § 1-5) Sec. 1-8. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. (a) The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. (b) The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. (Code 1969, § 1-6) Sec. 1-9. - Severability of parts of Code. It is hereby declared to be the intention of the City Council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code, since the same would have been enacted by the City Council without the incorporation in this Code of any such unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. (Code 1969, § 1-7) Sec. 1-10. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. (a) All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein. In the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code by the City Council. (b) Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section ____________ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Doraville, Georgia, is hereby amended to read as follows: …." The new provisions may then be set out in full as desired. (c) In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the Code of Ordinances, City of Doraville, Georgia, is hereby amended by adding a section (or article or chapter) to be numbered ____________ , which such section reads as follows: …." The new section may then be set out in full as desired. (d) All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. (Code 1969, § 1-8) Sec. 1-11. - Altering Code. It shall be unlawful for any person in the City to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever except by ordinance or resolution or other official act of the City Council, which will cause the law of the City of Doraville, Georgia, to be misrepresented thereby. Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-12. (Code 1969, § 1-9) State Law reference— Altering, falsifying or stealing public records unlawful, O.C.G.A. § 45-11-1. Sec. 1-12. - General penalty; continuing violations. (a) Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance of the City any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of such provision of this Code or any such ordinance shall be punished by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or imprisonment in the City jail or DeKalb County Jail for not more than six (6) months, subject to all limitations contained in the Charter of the City. Confinement shall be in the Doraville City Jail, the County Jail of DeKalb County or a state-approved public works camp. Each day any violation of this Code or of any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. (b) In addition to the penalties hereinabove provided, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this Code or any ordinance shall be deemed a public nuisance, and may be abated by the City as provided by law, and each day that such condition continues shall be regarded as a new and separate offense. (c) Civil citations. Whenever a provision of this Code provides for a civil citation to be issued, either by placement on a windshield of a vehicle or tacked onto the front door of a residence, it shall be done so in accordance with the following provisions. No citation issued in accordance with these provisions shall subject the recipient to any criminal penalties, including confinement or probation. (1) The citation shall be dated and identify with as much specificity as possible the source of the violation (i.e., the make/model/tag number of vehicle, address of the residence, appearance of animal, etc.) and location of the violation. The citation shall also state the violation, the fine and the consequences of the failure to pay the fine or request a court date to contest the alleged violation within ten (10) days of the issue date. The citation shall be signed by the officer issuing the citation. (2) It shall be unlawful for any person other than the owner or occupier of the residence, or owner or operator of the vehicle, to which the citation is attached, to remove any citation described in this subsection. (3) If the recipient of the citation chooses to contest the alleged violation, he/she shall request so in writing to the Doraville Municipal Court Clerk, stating the citation number and the violation in said notice, which shall be received by the Clerk (by facsimile, mail, or otherwise) no later than ten (10) days following the receipt of the citation. Upon receipt of the contest notice, the Court Clerk shall set the date of the hearing on said violation and notify the alleged violator of same in writing to the address listed in the contest notice. (4) At any hearing on the contest of the civil citation, the City shall have the burden to prove the violation by the preponderance of evidence, and shall not be deemed to be a criminal conviction and shall not affect the violator's driving or criminal record. (5) If the City meets its burden, the Court shall order the violator to pay the citation prior to leaving the courthouse that day. Failure to do so shall be considered contempt of court and may subject the violator to the punishment for same. (6) If an alleged violator has no unpaid civil citations, the City shall first issue a civil citation for applicable violations. If an alleged violator has more than one (1) unpaid civil citation, the City may charge the violator with a criminal citation, subject to all notice requirements therefor, and subject the alleged violator to all applicable criminal punishment as authorized by this Code, the City Charter and State law. (Code 1969, § 1-10; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1, 11-3-08; Ord. No. 2015-07 , § 1, 4-20-15) Charter reference— Maximum penalty, contempt, § 3.03. State Law reference— Penalty to be imposed in certain criminal and traffic cases and upon violation of bond, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-73; authority to confine persons convicted of violating ordinances, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-8; punishments authorized, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1(c); limitations on home rule powers, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6; revenues collected from fines and fees, O.C.G.A. § 47-17-60 et seq. Sec. 1-13. - Power to revoke permits or licenses. Unless otherwise stated, the City Manager or designee may revoke any permit or license issued under the provisions of this Code if there has been any false statement or misrepresentation as to any material fact in the application submitted for any permit or other use, or any false statement or misrepresentation made by any representative of the applicant therefor or the permittee, during the course of the application or permitting process, or for any other reason that is specifically designated by the applicable regulation of this Code. (Ord. No. 93-1, § 1-4-93; Ord. No. 2011-38, § 1, 11-7-11; Ord. No. 2013-11, § 1, 6-17-13) Sec. 1-14. - Notices: service of notices. Any notice required by this Code or the Doraville Zoning Ordinance may be served by either the City Manager or designee, an officer of the City police department, or by any other person who may be specifically authorized to give notice by a particular section or provision of the Code or the zoning ordinance. (Ord. No. 93-3, § 1, 1-4-93; Ord. No. 2013-11, § 5, 6-17-13) Sec. 1-15. - Hearing procedures. (a) City Manager or designee and Council. (1) [Appeal.] Where no other procedure to appeal an adverse decision rendered by the City Manager or designee pursuant to a City Code is otherwise designated, and where subsection (b) below is not referenced as the proper procedure to appeal the decision of the City Manager or designee or designee to deny, suspend or revoke any license or permit governed by the provisions of this Code, said decision may be appealed to the City Manager or designee and Council. Such appeal shall be by written petition filed in the City Clerk's office within fifteen (15) days after the final decision which shall be given to the applicant/license holder in writing by certified mail, which shall state the reason for the denial, suspension or revocation and shall notify the applicant or certificate holder of his right to procedural review of the denial, suspension or revocation in accordance with the procedures established herein. (2) Scheduling. A hearing shall be conducted on each appeal within thirty (30) days of the date of filing the written petition, unless a continuance of such hearing is agreed to by the appellant and the City Council. The appellant at such hearing shall have the right to be represented by an attorney at the expense of the appellant, and to present evidence and cross-examine witnesses. (3) Notice. Each appeal shall be heard by the City Manager or designee at the earliest practicable date following the receipt of an appeal request. The City Manager or designee shall send out a written notice of the time, date and place of the hearing to the appellant no later than ten (10) days prior to the hearing. Postponements will be granted only for good cause and at the discretion of the City Manager or designee. (4) Witnesses. Witnesses shall testify under oath. The City Council has the discretion to limit the number of witnesses requested by the appellant or the City if more than one witness is expected to testify to the same set of facts or to an excessive amount of character witnesses. The appellant may meet with the City Attorney prior to the hearing to agree on the number of witnesses. (5) Burden of proof. The burden of proof shall be on the City to show that the final decision was proper in accordance with the facts and appropriate law. The parties may give short opening statements, present and cross-examine witnesses and present closing statements. The rules of evidence shall not strictly apply. At the conclusion of the hearing, the Council may discuss the issues and render a final decision at that time or delay the rendering of said decision until the following regular or special-called meeting of the Council. (6) Findings. The Council may affirm the decision of the original decision-maker or reverse the decision only on a finding that it was based on error of fact or error in the interpretation of the relevant policy, regulation, ordinance or other applicable law. (7) Writ of Certiorari. The findings of the City Council shall be final unless appealed within thirty (30) days of the date of the findings by certiorari to the Superior Court of DeKalb County in accordance with Georgia law. (b) Hearing Officer. (1) [Appeal.] Where the City Code references this subsection to provide hearing procedure from any final decision of the City Manager or designee on any license or permit regulated by this Code, said decision may be appealed to a City-Council designated Hearing Officer. Such appeal shall be by written petition filed in the City Clerk's office within fifteen (15) days after the final decision which shall be given to the applicant/license holder in writing by certified mail, which shall state the reason for the denial, suspension or revocation and shall notify the applicant or certificate holder of his right to procedural review of the denial, suspension or revocation in accordance with the procedures established herein. (2) Notice. After a timely receipt of the notice of appeal, the City Clerk shall schedule a hearing in front of the City Council-designated Hearing Officer not later than thirty (30) days following the notice of appeal and shall notify the applicant or license/permit holder in writing of the date and time of said hearing no later than ten (10) days prior to the hearing. (3) Burden of proof. At the hearing, the City shall have the burden of proof by preponderance of the evidence that the denial, suspension or revocation was proper. The applicant or license/permit holder shall have the right to retain an attorney to represent him at the hearing, at the applicant or license/permit holder's expense. (4) Hearing. The City and the applicant or license/permit holder shall have the right to an opening statement, present evidence and cross-examine witnesses, and deliver a short closing statement. The rules of evidence shall not strictly apply and the Hearing Officer shall have discretion to exclude excessive or duplicative witness testimony or documentary evidence. The Hearing Officer shall make the decision to affirm or reverse the determination of the original decision maker no later than five (5) business days following the hearing and shall notify the applicant or license/permit holder of his decision in writing. The Hearing Officer's decision shall be final. The Hearing Officer may reverse the decision only on a finding that it was based on error of fact or error in the interpretation of the relevant policy, regulation, ordinance or other applicable law. (5) Writ of Certiorari. The findings of the Hearing Officer shall be final unless appealed within thirty (30) days of the date of the findings by certiorari to the Superior Court of DeKalb County in accordance with Georgia law. (6) Hearing Officer qualifications. The Hearing Officer shall be an attorney with not less than three (3) years experience in the practice of law, licensed by the State of Georgia and with an office no closer than five (5) miles outside the geographic boundaries of the City of Doraville, Georgia. The City Clerk shall maintain a list of qualified Hearing Officers, and such Officers shall be appointed consecutively according to such list based upon availability. The compensation of such Hearing Officers shall not exceed one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per hour. (Ord. No. 2011-04, § 1, 2-22-11; Ord. No. 2011-38, § 2, 11-7-11; Ord. No. 2013-11, §§ 2, 3, 6-17-13) Editor's note— Section 2 of Ord. No. 2011-38, adopted Nov. 7, 2011, changed the title of § 1-15 from "Hearing procedure for regulated businesses" to "Hearing procedures."

div.head: Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— The City employees' retirement plan as set forth in Ord. No. 188 dated 8-3-76 and Ord. No. 188-A dated 8-19-76, is compiled and published separately by the City and is available for inspection and review in the office of the City Clerk. State Law reference— Powers relating to administration of government generally, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2; The Municipal Home Rule Act of 1965, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 2-1. - Official newspaper designated. A newspaper having a general circulation within the City shall be designated by resolution of the City Council as the official organ of the City. Such resolution shall be published for four (4) consecutive weeks in the official organ and a copy permanently posted in a place available to the public in the City Hall. (Code 1969, § 2-4; Ord. No. 05-24, § 1, 6-20-05) Sec. 2-2. - Availability of City records. (a) Except where otherwise expressly provided, all ordinances, resolutions, minutes and records of the City and of its governing authorities, and all of the records of the various departments of the City, are and shall be treated as public records. (b) Any citizen shall have the right to see and read the public records on request at any reasonable time, provided this right shall not be abused. In order to avail himself of this right any person desiring to see and read any record shall point it out or sufficiently describe it to enable the officer or employee of the City in charge thereof to locate the same without unnecessary waste of time. (Code 1969, § 2-5) Sec. 2-3. - Filing of ordinance, resolution after first reading. Every ordinance and resolution read the first time in the Council shall be filed with the City Clerk, who shall safely keep and retain the same as a part of the permanent records of the City, whether finally adopted or defeated. (Code 1969, § 2-6) Charter reference— City legislation, § 2.09; readings, § 2.10. Sec. 2-3.5. - Paraphrasing ordinance in lieu of reading. A City depository shall be designated from time to time by motion of the City Council. (Code 1969, § 2-8) Sec. 2-6. - City Clerk and Treasurer; offices combined. The office of the City Clerk and City Treasurer are hereby combined. It shall be the duty of the City Clerk to discharge the duties of City Clerk and the duties of City Treasurer. No official or employee of the City shall have the authority to incur any indebtedness against the City without first securing a purchase order therefor from the purchasing agent as above provided. Any such official or employee found violating this section shall be held strictly accountable therefor and liable to removal from office within the discretion of the City Council (for elected officials or Council-appointed officials) or the City Manager (all other officials and employees). (Code 1969, § 2-54; Ord. No. 2013-11, § 6, 6-17-13) Sec. 2-9. - Legal department. (a) A legal department for the City is hereby created to consist of the City Attorney and such assistants and clerks as may be appointed by or with the approval and consent of the Council. (b) The salary of the City Attorney, his assistants and clerks shall be fixed by the Council. (c) The City Attorney or an assistant City Attorney shall attend all regular meetings of the Council unless excused by the chairman, and render opinions when called upon to do so by the Mayor or the City Council. It shall be the duty of the City Attorney to see that this section is carried out. If the City Attorney is unable for any cause to attend a regular Council meeting, he shall notify an assistant City Attorney to be present at such meeting. (Code 1969, §§ 2-20—2-22) Charter reference— City Attorney, § 2.14. Sec. 2-10. - Social Security benefits. It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the City to extend the benefits of the system of Old Age and Survivors Insurance as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act, the State Enabling Act, and amendments thereto. In pursuance of such policy, and for that purpose, the City shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (Code 1969, § 11-23) Sec. 2-11. - Filing notice of candidacy and establishing hours when qualifying shall be conducted. (a) Each candidate, except a candidate nominated by nomination petition provided for in Subsection (f) of O.C.G.A. § 21-3-91, or a designee shall file a notice of candidacy in the office of the municipal superintendent: (1) In the case of a general election held in an odd-numbered year, no earlier than 8:30 a.m. on the second Monday in September immediately preceding the general election and no later than 4:30 p.m. on the following Friday; (2) In the case of a general election held in an even-numbered year, no earlier than 8:30 a.m. on the last Monday in August immediately preceding the general election and no later than 4:30 p.m. on the following Friday; and (3) In the case of a special election, at least twenty-five (25) days prior to the election. The hours of qualifying each day shall be from 8:30 a.m. until 4:30 p.m. with one (1) hour allowed for the lunch break; provided, however, that if the City has normal business hours which cover a lesser period of time then the City shall conduct qualifying during such normal business hours. If a run-off is held, each candidate nominated therein or a designee shall file a notice of candidacy with the municipal superintendent within three (3) days after the holding of such election, irrespective of such three-day period's exceeding a qualification deadline prescribed in this subsection. Notice of the opening and closing dates and the hours for candidates to qualify shall be published at least two (2) weeks prior to the opening of the qualifying period. (Ord. No. 199, § 1, 1-15-79; Ord. No. 93-11, § 1, 8-2-93; Ord. No. 95-15, § 1, 8-7-95) Charter reference— Elections, § 5.01 et seq. Sec. 2-12. - Qualification fees for candidates. Not later than February 1 of any year in which a general election is to be held, and at least thirty-five (35) days prior to the special election in the case of a special election, the Mayor and City Council shall fix and publish a qualifying fee for each municipal office to be filled in the upcoming election. Such fee shall be paid to the City Clerk at the time a candidate files the candidate's notice of candidacy. Such fee shall be three (3) percent of the annual salary of the office if a salaried office. If not a salaried office, the Mayor and City Council shall be authorized to fix and publish a qualification fee not to exceed thirty-five dollars ($35.00) for such an office. (Ord. No. 95-16, § 1, 8-7-95; Ord. No. 05-26, § 1, 6-20-05) Secs. 2-13—2-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL
Sec. 2-31. - City Council meetings. Council may, in its discretion, waive the meeting held on the third Monday during the months of June, July, August and December. In unusual situations, the Council may reschedule the regular meeting on the following day by majority vote. (Code 1969, § 2-1(a), (b); Ord. No. 160, § 1, 3-6-72; Ord. No. 160-A, § I, 2-10-76; Ord. No. 2013-1, § 1, adopted Jan. 22, 2013. Said ordinance subsequently renumbered §§ 2-37 as 2-33, §§ 2-40—2-43 as 2-34—2-37. Sec. 2-34. - Planning Commission. (a) Definitions. (1) Zoning proposal, under this section, shall mean any application or request for rezoning of land by the City or any other party and zoning ordinance text amendments. (2) Zoning variance shall mean a divergence from strict compliance with a zoning ordinance when a duly authorized body determines, based upon the application of objective standards to the evidence shown, that extraordinary conditions exist warranting such divergence. (b) The Mayor and City Council hereby establish a Planning Commission for the City pursuant to the City Charter Section 2.16. (c) The Planning Commission shall consist of five (5) appointed members, each of whom shall serve a maximum of two (2) consecutive four-year terms. A period of two (2) years shall elapse before any member serving the maximum two (2) consecutive terms shall be eligible to serve again on the Planning Commission. The members shall be residents of the City for at least one (1) year prior to taking office. The Council shall select one (1) member from each district and two (2) at-large members who may reside in any district. In order to achieve staggered terms, the members representing the districts shall serve an initial term ending April 1, 2010, and the two (2) at-large members shall serve initial terms ending April 1, 2008. If a position becomes vacant, a member shall be appointed, from the vacated district or at-large, by the City Council to serve the remainder of the term. (d) The Council shall solicit residents of the City to volunteer to serve on the Planning Commission. Any member of the commission may be removed from office by a vote of a majority of the members of the City Council. Any vacancy in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by appointment of the City Council. Planning Commission members are encouraged to attend training through the Atlanta Regional Commission and other locally provided workshops as soon as reasonably possible after their appointment. Pre-approved training and reasonable expenses shall be paid for by the City. (e) The Planning Commission shall elect its chairman and vice chairman from among its members. The chairman and vice chairman shall serve for one (1) year or until they are re-elected or their successors are elected. The Planning Commission shall appoint a secretary-treasurer who may be an officer or an employee of the City. The Planning Commission shall make its own rules of procedures not in conflict with state law or local ordinance and determine its time of meeting. All meetings of the Planning Commission shall be open to the public and all records of the Planning Commission shall be a public record. (f) The Planning Commission shall be advisory in nature. (g) From and after the time when the Planning Commission shall have organized and selected its officers and shall have adopted its rules of procedure, then the Planning Commission shall, with respect to each zoning proposal and zoning variance as defined in this section, investigate and make a nonbinding recommendation with respect to each of the matters enumerated in the zoning ordinances, as well as carrying out any other duties with which the Planning Commission is charged by the City Council. (h) The Planning Commission shall be required to consider and adhere to the criteria established as set forth in the Code of Ordinances of the City of Doraville in making such zoning and variance investigations and recommendations. (i) The authority of the Planning Commission shall consist of review and recommendations on zoning decisions and zoning variances as defined herein. The Planning Commission shall not consider administrative variances as set out in the Zoning Ordinance. (j) After any matter has been presented to the Planning Commission, the Planning Commission shall render a final recommendation to the Mayor and Council either approving, denying or approving with conditions or forwarding the matter to City Council without recommendation no later than at the next Planning Commission meeting. If the Planning Commission fails to forward its recommendations on an item within sixty (60) days of its first review of same, such item shall still be forwarded to the next available City Council meeting without recommendation. On text amendments initiated by the City, or applications for zoning action where significant and material changes are being proposed, the Mayor and City Council may, by majority vote and only with consent of the applicant, return an item which arrived without recommendation from the Planning Commission back to the Planning Commission for additional review and recommendation at the next scheduled Planning Commission Meeting. Additionally, on text amendments initiated by the City Council, the City Council may designate additional time for the Planning Commission to review the item at the time of the text amendment initiation for the purpose of making sure that the Planning Commission has an appropriate amount of time to meaningfully review and issue a recommendation to the Council on the proposed text amendment. (k) The Planning Commission shall meet on the first Wednesday of the month and when any agenda item is placed before the Planning Commission by the Mayor and Council, when any item is placed on the agenda by City staff and/or when any item has been previously heard and tabled by the Planning Commission. (Ord. No. 06-06, § 1, 2-6-06; Ord. No. 2008-15, § 1, 9-25-08; Ord. No. 2009-05, § 1, 3-19-09; Ord. No. 2011-16, § 1, 4-4-11; Ord. No. 2013-14, § 1, 7-15-13; Ord. No. 2014-05, § 1, 3-17-14) Editor's note— See editor's note to § 2-33. Sec. 2-35. - Section relative to emergency management. (a) Definition. As used in this section, the term "emergency management" shall mean the preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency and disaster functions other than those functions for which military forces or state and federal agencies are primarily responsible, to prevent, minimize, and repair injury and damage resulting from emergencies or disasters, or the imminent threat thereof, of manmade or natural origin. These functions may include, without limitation, fire-fighting services, police services, medical and health services, rescue, engineering, warning services, communications, protection against the effects of radiological, chemical and other special weapons, evacuation of persons from stricken areas, emergency welfare services, emergency transportation, plant protection, shelter, temporary restoration of public utility services, and other functions related to civilian population, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to total emergency and disaster preparedness for carrying out the foregoing functions. (b) Office of the DeKalb County Emergency Management Director. It is the desire and intent of the governing officials of the City of Doraville, Georgia that the City be a part of the DeKalb County Emergency Management Unit. The Chief Executive Officer of DeKalb County shall nominate for appointment, by the governor, a director of emergency management for the entire county. When appointed, the emergency management director is charged with the following duties: (1) To represent the governing officials of the City on matters pertaining to emergency management. (2) To assist City officials in organizing City departments for emergency operations. (3) To develop, in conjunction with City and county departments, the DeKalb County Emergency and Disaster Operations Plan emergency functions set forth in subsection (a) of this section. The plan will be in consonance with the Georgia Natural Disaster Operations Plan and Nuclear Emergency Operations Plan, and shall be submitted to the governing officials of DeKalb County and the cities therein for approval, and thence to the Georgia Emergency Management Agency for approval. (4) To maintain the emergency management office and carry out the day-to-day administration of the DeKalb County Emergency Management Program, including the submission of required reports, to the Georgia Emergency Management Agency. (5) To submit reports as required by governing officials in keeping with good management practices, e.g., financial, daily activity, etc. (6) To obtain, with the authority of governing officials, a facility to be used as the DeKalb County Emergency Operating Center. (7) To coordinate the activities of the DeKalb County Emergency Operating Center staff during periods of an emergency, and under the supervision of DeKalb County governing officials. (c) Dekalb County Emergency Management Office. The DeKalb County Emergency Office shall be established around existing City and county departments and the emergency functions described in subsection (a) above are assigned as follows:
(d) Powers during an emergency or disaster. In the event of a manmade or natural disaster, actual enemy attack upon the United States, or any other emergency which may affect the lives and property of the citizens of the City, the Mayor of the City separately, or jointly with the CEO, county commissioners, or in their absences, their legally appointed successors, may determine that an emergency or disaster exists and thereafter shall have and may exercise for such period as such emergency or disaster exists or continues, the following powers: (1) To enforce all rules, laws and regulations relating to emergency management, and to assume direct operational control over all emergency management resources; (2) To seize or take for temporary use, any private property for the protection of the public; (3) To sell, lend, give or distribute all or any such property or supplies among the inhabitants of the county and to maintain a strict accounting of property or supplies distributed and for funds received for such property or supplies; (4) And, to perform and exercise such other functions and duties, and take such emergency actions as may be necessary to promote and secure the safety, protection and well-being of the inhabitants of the county. (e) Volunteers. All persons, other than officers and employees of the City, performing emergency functions pursuant to this section, shall serve with or without compensation. While engaged in such emergency functions, duly assigned volunteers shall have the same immunities as City officers and employees. (Ord. No. 92-13, § 1, 12-7-92; Ord. No. 2013-14, § 1, 7-15-13) Editor's note— See editor's note to § 2-33. Sec. 2-36. - Restriction on audible equipment in meetings of the City Council and at sessions of the municipal court. In addition to any and all powers enumerated in the City Code, the Mayor, as the chief executive of the City, shall have the right to declare an emergency to exist when, in his opinion, one (1) or more of the following conditions exist: (1) That there is extreme likelihood of danger of destruction of life or property due to unusual conditions. (2) Unusual or extreme weather conditions, making use of City streets or areas difficult or impossible. (3) Civil unrest, commotion or uprising is imminent or exists. (4) There is a stoppage or loss of electrical power affecting a major portion of the City. (Code 1969, § 2-81) Sec. 2-58. - Powers of City Manager after declaration of emergency. After Mayor's declaration of emergency, the City Manager or designee shall have the right to exercise any or all of the following powers: (1) To use employees of the City to assist in the safety and preservation of life, limb and property of the citizenry of the City. (2) To close streets and sidewalks and to delineate areas within the City wherein an emergency exists. (3) To impose emergency curfew regulations. (4) To close any and all municipally owned buildings and other facilities to the use of the general public. (5) To do any and all acts necessary and incidental to the preservation of life, limb and property of the citizenry of the City. (Code 1969, § 2-82; Ord. Const. art. 9, sec. 4, par. 2; discretion of governing body as to management and disposition of property, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-2; acquisition, sale and lease of real and personal property, O.C.G.A. § 36-37-1; disposition of municipal property, O.C.G.A. § 36-37-6; multiyear lease, purchase or lease purchase contracts, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-13; budgets and audits, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-1 et seq.; accounting for public funds, O.C.G.A. § 45-8-1 et seq.; local political subdivision purchases, O.C.G.A. § 50-5-100 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 2-106. - Use restricted; user's responsibility. It shall be unlawful for any person to allow or permit the use of any City buildings or recreation center except to a financially responsible person. Such authority shall set forth the name and address of such financially responsible person granted such permission, and state the time such building shall be used and by whom and for what purpose, and clearly state that the person granted the permit shall be responsible for such building and contents thereof. (Code 1969, § 2-34) Sec. 2-107. - Use for unauthorized purpose prohibited. It shall be an offense for any person to use any City building for any purpose other than the purpose for which such building is let to such person. The chief of police shall see that this section is carried out and enforced. (Code 1969, § 2-35) Sec. 2-108. - Permission for use required. (a) Any person desiring to use the City property for charitable, religious, patriotic, civic, fraternal or other similar purposes not for gain must make an application and obtain permission from the City Council. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to have or use the municipal auditorium for any activity, exhibition, wrestling match, prize fight, show, performance or any other things to promote any profitable or commercial transaction or business or activity the chief or principal purpose of which is commercial gain or profit without first obtaining permission from the City Council. (Code 1969, § 2-36) Sec. 2-109. - Surrender of keys. The City Manager or designee shall be custodian of keys to the municipal buildings located within the City. It shall be the duty of every person to whom a key is issued under this section, upon suspension, discharge, removal or discontinuance of the services to the City, to immediately surrender such keys to the custodian. (Code 1969, § 2-37; Ord. No. 2013-11, § 9, 6-17-13) Editor's note— Section 9 of Ord. No. 2013-11, adopted June 17, 2013, changed the title of § 2-109 from "Surrender of keys to clerk" to "Surrender of keys." Sec. 2-110. - Liability for damage to City buildings. Any person using any City building or property shall be liable for any damages to such buildings as a result of such use. (Code 1969, § 2-38) Sec. 2-111. - Donations of City property, funds to churches, etc., prohibited. Donations and contributions of City property, funds and services to churches and religious organizations by the City are hereby prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any City funds, services or property to be contributed, donated or given to any church, religious or sectarian body or institution. (Code 1969, § 2-39) Sec. 2-112. - Use of City funds, property, services of personnel for private purposes prohibited; penalty. (a) It shall be unlawful for City funds, City property or services of personnel to be used when or where it is primarily for the benefit of any private person as distinguished from the public. It shall be likewise unlawful for any private person to receive any City funds, property or services of City personnel under circumstances mentioned in this section. (b) Any person violating any provision of this section shall, upon conviction thereof in the municipal court, be punished as provided in section 1-12. If the offender is an officer or employee of the City, such officer or employee shall, in addition to other penalties imposed, be subject to suspension definite or indefinite, demotion, removal or discharge in the discretion of the City Council. (Code 1969, § 2-40) Sec. 2-113. - Sale of personal property; procedure. (a) When it is deemed advisable to dispose of any personal property belonging to the City and used in the various departments thereof, or under the supervision of the City Manager or Mayor and Council, the sale of such property shall be made by the City Manager through a representative of the City Manager. The purchasing agent shall confer with the head of the department selling the property, with the view to getting the best price possible in making the sale. This section is not intended to authorize the sale of such property without a resolution of the Council, but where a resolution has, for any reason, provided for the sale of any such property belonging to the City, the sale of such property shall be supervised by the City Manager acting with the proper official of the City familiar with and in charge of the property proposed to be sold. (b) When any property owned by the City in the possession of its various departments has become worn out or useless, or has become junk or has been used to such an extent that it is advisable to dispose of same, the head of the department in charge of such property shall certify to the Council that certain itemized property is in possession of the department and is no longer useful in the service of the City and thereupon with authorization of the Council shall, at public or private sale, sell such property and turn the proceeds thereof over to the City Treasurer, crediting the department from which such property was obtained with the amount of same. Private sales of any such property requires approval by the City Council. No sale of such property shall be made by the Council where other provisions are made under other ordinances for such sales, but this section shall apply only to property of the kind named for the sale of which no provision is otherwise made; provided, however, the Council is hereby authorized to dispose of obsolete or worn out material accumulated in the various departments to the best advantage of the City by selling, trading or transferring, whichever in its discretion will be most advantageous to the City, or such property may be abandoned by motion of the City Council. (c) All public sales by the purchasing agent shall be advertised at least one (1) time in the official gazette of the City and by posting a notice of the time, place and terms of sale and describing the property to be sold in at least three (3) public places in the City, including the bulletin board in the lobby of the City Hall; provided, after a public offering of property for sale by the purchasing agent as provided in this section, it shall be lawful for the City Council to sell at private sale if same is deemed appropriate. (Code 1969, § 2-41; Ord. No. 2013-11, § 10, 6-17-13) Secs. 2-114—2-130. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PROPERTY IN HANDS OF POLICE DEPARTMENT
Sec. 2-131. - Sale authorized. The police department shall have the authority to sell at public outcry to the highest bidder for cash any and all articles of personal property that have come into the hands of the police department and which, after diligent effort has been made to ascertain the true and lawful owner thereof without success, remain unclaimed for a period of at least three (3) months. (Ord. No. 184, § I, 1-19-76) Sec. 2-132. - Record; identification of property. The police department shall maintain a separate and complete catalog record of all property coming into its hands, such property to be identified in detail by its usual name, make and model, manufacturer's name and serial number, if any, and if no identifying name or numbers, to be fully described on such catalog record as to its physical properties and appearance. Such record shall also show the date such property came into the hands of the department and the disposal thereof. (Ord. No. 184, § II, 1-19-76) Sec. 2-133. - Attempt to find owner. It shall be the duty of the police department to make a diligent effort to find the true owner of any article of personal property coming into its hands, and if such owner can be found to deliver such property to him. If the true owner of any such article cannot be found and the property remains unclaimed for a period of not less than three (3) months next preceding the date of sale as hereinafter provided, the department may proceed to sell such article as hereinafter provided. (Ord. No. 184, § III, 1-19-76) Sec. 2-134. - Location, manner of sale. The police department may hold a public sale of all unclaimed articles of personal property held by it for at least three (3) months immediately preceding the date of sale at the headquarters of the police department. The date, time and location of such sale shall be established by the Mayor and City Council. All articles sold shall be sold for cash to the highest bidder on an "as is" basis, and no warranties of any nature, either express or implied, either as to merchantability, title, quality, or performance, or fitness for a particular purpose, shall be made by the police department. (Ord. No. 184-A, § I, 10-2-89) Sec. 2-135. - Notice of sale. The sale referred to in this division shall be advertised in a newspaper of general circulation in the county, as well as the City, once each week for two (2) weeks immediately preceding the next sale date. The advertisement shall be of sufficient size and type to be easily read and understood by the general public and shall state definitely the time and place of such sale; that it shall be open to the public; and that all sales are to be made to the highest bidder for cash. Such advertisement may refer to the sale as an "Ole Hoss" sale or by any other appropriate name and shall state that only unclaimed property which has come into possession of the police department is being sold; that the police department makes no warranties whatsoever, either expressed or implied, as to merchantability, merchantable title, quality or performance, or fitness for a particular purpose, and all articles are sold "as is." (Ord. No. 184, § V, 1-19-76) Sec. 2-136. - Auctioneer. The police department shall appoint a licensed auctioneer, a member of its own force or any other individual, to conduct the sale authorized by this division under the guidance of an employee of the police department and more than one (1) such person may act at any sale, either alternately or at the same time as the circumstances may dictate and in the discretion of the employee of the department who is in charge of the sale. The auctioneer or other individual acting shall be the sole arbiter in the case of a disputed sale and he shall not make a sale until all bidding on the article offered has ceased; however, there shall be no required number of bids before a sale is made. (Ord. No. 184, § VI, 1-19-76) Sec. 2-137. - Sales not warranted. It shall be the duty of the auctioneer or other person holding a sale under this division to make public announcement before opening such sale that the police department does not warrant title to any article, nor is there any other warranty, either as to merchantability or fitness for a particular purpose, either expressed or implied, as to any article sold; that all sales are final and all articles are sold "as is." It shall be the duty of such auctioneer or other person in charge to make this announcement at intervals during the progress of the sales. (Ord. No. 184, § VII, 1-19-76) Sec. 2-138. - Accounting, disposition of receipts. It shall be the duty of the police department to make a true accounting to the City of all the property sold under this division and money collected from the sales conducted as provided herein, which money shall be paid into the general fund of the City. (Ord. No. 184, § VIII, 1-19-76; Ord. No. 184-A, § I, 10-2-89) Secs. 2-139—2-145. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - NON-SMOKING AT HONEYSUCKLE PARK
Sec. 2-146. - No smoking. (a) All smoking or use of tobacco products is prohibited at Honeysuckle Park. The term "Honeysuckle Park" is deemed to include all vehicle City parking areas appurtenant to the park. (b) Violations of subsection (a) shall be punishable in accordance with section 1-12 of this Code. (Ord. No. 2010-19, § 1, 8-2-10) Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 2010-19, adopted Aug. 2, 2010, amended the Code by the addition of div. 3, § 2-114. However, said provision has been redesignated as div. 3, § 2-146 at the editor's discretion, for purposes of maintaining the sequential numbering of the Code. Secs. 2-147—2-155. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - CODE OF ETHICS[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, adopted Sept. 2, 2008, repealed the former art. VI, §§ 2-156—2-185.11, and art. X, §§ 2-250—2-258, and enacted a new art. X, §§ 2-250—2-290. The former art. VI pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 06-25, adopted Nov. 6, 2006. Subsequently, Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, adopted Nov. 16, 2009, renumbered art. X, §§ 2-250—2-290 as art. VI, §§ 2-156—2-185.11, and readopted the formerly repealed art. X, §§ 2-250—2-258 as a new art. X, §§ 2-250—2-258.
Sec. 2-156. - Intent. The citizens and businesses of the City of Doraville (the "City") are entitled to have fair, ethical and accountable local government which has earned the public's full confidence for integrity. Further, it is essential to the proper administration and operation of the City that the members of its City Council, the members of appointed boards, committees and commissions and the employees of the City treat each other with respect and be, and give the appearance of being, independent and impartial; that public office or position not be used for private gain; that there be public confidence in the integrity of the members of the City Council, the members of appointed boards, committees and commissions and the employees of the City, and that the public interest requires protection against conflicts of interest by establishing and adopting appropriate ethical standards to govern the conduct of the members of the City Council, the members of appointed boards, committees and commissions and employees of the City. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-157. - Definitions. (a) Appointee shall be any person appointed to a board, committee or commission by the City Council or Mayor. (b) City Council member shall be any person who is a City Council member, including the Mayor of the City. (c) City employee shall be any person who is a full-time or part-time employee of the City. (d) Family member means the spouse, mother, father, brother, sister, son or daughter of a City Council member of an Appointee or the spouse-in-law, mother-in-law, father-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, son-in-law or daughter-in-law of a City Council member of an Appointee. (e) Financial interest means all direct ownership interests of the total assets or capital stock of a business entity where such ownership interest is ten (10) percent or more. (f) Government or City shall be construed to mean the City of Doraville, Georgia government. (g) Member shall include City Councilmembers and members of appointed boards, committees and commissions. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-158. - Conduct of members and City employees. The professional and personal conduct of members and City employees must be above reproach and avoid even the appearance of impropriety. Members and City employees shall refrain from abusive conduct, personal charges or verbal attacks upon the character or motives of other members of the City Council, appointees, City employees or members of the public. Every person appearing before the City Council, a City board, committee or commission, or meeting with a City Council or a City employee on City business shall be treated with courtesy and respect. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-159. - Act in the public interest. Recognizing that stewardship of the public interest must be their primary concern, members will work for the common good of the people of the City and not for any private or personal interest in accordance with the processes and rules of order established by the City Council and City boards, committees and commissions governing the deliberation of public policy issues. Members will assure fair and equal treatment of all persons, claims and transactions coming before the City Council, boards, committees and commissions. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-160. - Comply with the law. Members and City employees shall comply with the laws of the United States, the State of Georgia, and the City in the performance of their public duties. These laws include, but are not limited to: The United States and Georgia Constitutions; laws pertaining to conflicts of interest, election, campaigns, financial disclosures, employer responsibilities, and open processes of government; and City ordinances and policies. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-161. - Conduct of public meetings. Members shall prepare themselves for public issues; listen courteously and attentively to all public discussions before the body; and focus on the business at hand. They shall refrain from interrupting other speakers, making personal comments not germane to the business of the body, or otherwise interfering with the orderly conduct of meetings. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-162. - Decisions based on merit. Members shall base their decisions on the merits and substance of the matter at hand. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-163. - Communication. Members shall publicly share substantive information that is relevant to a matter under consideration by the City Council or boards, committees or commissions which they may have received from sources outside the public decision-making process. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-164. - Advocacy. Members shall represent the official policies or positions of the City Council, boards, committees and commissions to the best of their ability when designated as delegates for this purpose. When presenting their individual opinions and positions, members shall explicitly state they do not represent their body or the City, nor will they allow the inference that they do. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-165. - Policy role of members. Members shall respect and adhere to the structure of government of the City as outlined in the City's Charter and policies and procedures. In this structure, the City Council determines the policies of the City with the advice, information and analysis provided by the public, boards, committees, commissions, and City employees. Members serving as liaisons to City departments shall serve to facilitate communications and information from those departments to City Council, but shall not direct the activities of the department directors. Members shall not interfere with the day-to-day administrative functions of the City or the professional duties of the City employees; nor shall they impair the ability of City employees to implement City Council policy decisions. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-166. - Independence of boards, committees and commissions. Because of the value of the independent advice of boards, committees and commissions to the public decision-making process, members of the City Council shall refrain from using their position to influence unduly the deliberations or outcomes of board, committee and commission proceedings. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-167. - Acceptance of gifts. (a) Neither members nor City employees shall solicit or accept directly or indirectly anything of value from any person, corporation, or group which: (1) Has, or is seeking to obtain contractual or other business or financial relationships with the City; (2) In exchange for the thing of value seeks to have a member or City employee exercise a matter of discretion in his or her favor; (3) In exchange for the thing of value seeks to have interests which may be affected by the performance or nonperformance of the official duty of the member. (b) Neither members or City employees shall directly or indirectly request, exact, receive, or agree to receive a gift, loan, favor, promise, or thing of value for him/herself or another person if: (1) It could reasonably be considered to influence the member in the discharge of his or her official duties. (2) The member or City employee recently has been, or is now or within six months in the future, involved in any official act or action which results in a pecuniary benefit for the donor or lender which is not available to the public at large. (c) The above prohibitions shall not apply in the case of: (1) Occasional nonpecuniary gift or insignificant trinkets or gifts such as a calendar, memento or pen received in the normal course of business with a value of less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and admission to and or consumption of food at a breakfast, lunch, diner, function or event; (2) Award publicly presented in recognition of public service; (3) Transaction authorized by and performed in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 16-10-6 as now or hereafter amended; (4) A commercially reasonable loan or other financial transaction made in the ordinary course of business by an institution or individual authorized by the laws of Georgia to engage in the making of such loan or financial transaction; or (5) Campaign contributions made and reported in accordance with Georgia law. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-168. - Financial interests of members. Members may not: (1) Have direct or indirect financial interests that conflict substantially with their responsibilities and duties as government servants; or (2) Engage in, directly or indirectly, financial transactions as a result of, or primarily relying upon, information obtained from their office. Aside from these restrictions, members are free to engage in lawful financial transactions to the same extent as private citizens. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-169. - Use of public property. Neither a member or City employee shall use City property of any kind for other than officially approved activities, nor shall he or she direct City employees to use such property for these purposes. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-170. - Use of confidential information. Members shall respect the confidentiality of information concerning City property, personnel or proceedings of the City. A member shall not directly or indirectly make use of, or permit others to make use of, for the purpose of furthering a private interest, official information not made available to the general public. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-171. - Coercion by members. A member shall not use his or her position in any way to coerce, or give the appearance of coercing, another person to provide any financial benefit to him or her or a family member, or those with whom a member has a financial interest. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-172. - Voting in matters of personal interest. (a) A member shall not vote on an ordinance or amendment for a specific item in a City Council meeting that would directly affect his or her private business. Provided, however, that in the event of an ordinance of general application or a matter of City-wide application, or in the event such vote would be proper under section 2-178, such member shall disclose such interest and, following such disclosure, shall be allowed to vote on such matter and such vote shall not constitute a violation of these rules and shall no be the subject matter of an ethics complaint hereunder. (b) Appointee shall not vote on a matter that would directly affect his or her private business. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-173. - Unauthorized purchases. Neither a member or City employee shall have any goods and services for the City without prior official authorization for such an expenditure. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-174. - City Attorneys used for private business. Neither a member or City employee shall use the City Attorney for personal or private business without paying just compensation. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-175. - Unauthorized use of City employees. A member shall not use his or her superior position to request or require a City employee to: (1) Do clerical work on behalf of a family member, business, social, church or fraternal interests; (2) Purchase goods and services to be used for personal, business or political purposes; and (3) Work for him or her personally without offering him or her just compensation. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-176. - Travel expenses. Neither a member or City employee shall draw per diem or expense monies from the City to attend a seminar, convention or conference and then fail to attend the seminar, convention or conference without refunding the pro-rated unused per diem or expense monies to the City. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-177. - Restrictions on contracts with former members. The City shall not enter into any contract with any person or business represented by such person, who has been within the preceding twelve-month period a member or City employees, unless the contract is awarded by a competitive bid or a committee selection process. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-178. - Voting on general matters. Elected officials are required to consider many matters as part of their official duties, including zoning matters, budgeting matters and many other items of public business. In that regard, a complaint alleging a violation of such a matter must be alleged and proved beyond a reasonable doubt by clear and convincing evidence. Nothing shall be construed to prohibit a City Council member from voting on amendments to the zoning code, amendment to the future land use plan, amendments to the comprehensive plan, ordinances, resolutions, code sections, proclamations or the annual budget or general budget amendments when the City Councilmembers are voting upon a revision of the above initiated by the City Councilmembers, unless the City Council member or a member of his or her family has a financial interest in a budgeted item or other item set out in this sentence. (Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 9-2-08; Ord. No. 2009-32, § 1, 11-16-09) Sec. 2-179. - Penalties. The code of ethics to be observed by members is set forth above and any violation thereof shall subject the offender to disciplinary action which may include censure and either public or private reprimand.
