The homestead exemption shall be returned and claimed as provided herein: (1) A person shall not receive the homestead exemption granted by this article unless the person or person's agent files an application with the governing authority of the City of Doraville, or the designee thereof, giving such information relative to receiving such exemption as will enable the governing authority of the City, or designee thereof, to make a determination regarding the initial and continuing eligibility of such owner for such exemption. The governing authority of the City, or designee thereof, shall provide application forms for this purpose. (2) The exemption shall be claimed and returned as provided in O.C.G.A. § 40-5-50.1, as amended. The exemption shall be automatically renewed from year to year as long as the owner occupies the residence as a homestead. After a person has filed the proper application as provided in this article, it shall not be necessary to make application thereafter for any year, and the exemption shall continue to be allowed to such person. It shall be the duty of any person granted the homestead exemption under this article to notify the governing authority of the City of Doraville, or the designee thereof, in the event that person for any reason becomes ineligible for that exemption. (Ord. No. 209, § III, 3-16-81; Ord. No. 05-12, § 1(D), 4-18-05; Ord. No. 2013-12, § 9, 6-17-13) Sec. 18-54. - Violations. Any person knowingly filing for or returning a homestead exemption under this article when such person is not entitled thereto or continuing to claim the homestead when he is no longer eligible to claim same, or any person knowingly submitting an application for the homestead exemption which contains materially false information, shall be guilty of a violation of this division, and shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-12 of this Code. (Ord. No. 209, § IV, 3-16-81) Secs. 18-55—18-69. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - RENTAL MOTOR VEHICLES EXCISE TAX
Sec. 18-70. - Intent and statutory authority. The intent hereof is to establish and impose a rental motor vehicle excise tax pursuant to the authority and terms of Title 28, Chapter 13, Article 5 of the O.C.G.A., the funds or revenues from which taxation shall be used and expended for all lawful purposes, in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-93. (Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-17-12) Sec. 18-71 - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Month or monthly period means the calendar months of any year. Motor vehicle means a motor vehicle designed to carry ten (10) or fewer passengers and used primarily for the transportation of persons that is rented or leased without a driver regardless of whether such vehicle is licensed in the state. Rental charge means the total value received by a rental motor vehicle concern for the rental or lease of thirty-one (31) or fewer consecutive days of a rental motor vehicle, including the total cash and nonmonetary consideration for the rental or lease including, but not limited to, charges based on time or mileage and charges for insurance coverage or collision damage waiver, but excluding all charges for motor fuel taxes or sales taxes. Rental motor vehicle concern means a person or legal entity which owns or leases five (5) or more rental motor vehicles and which regularly rents or leases such vehicles to the public for value. Tax, excise tax or taxes means the tax imposed by this article. (Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-17-12) Sec. 18-72. - Penalty for violation. In addition to the interest charges and delinquent penalties specified in this article, any person violating any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in this Code. Such persons shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during which any violation of any provision of this article is committed, continued, or permitted by that person and shall be punished accordingly. (Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-17-12) Sec. 18-73. - Authority and records. (a) The City Finance Director and City Clerk shall administer and enforce this article for the levy and collection of the tax. (b) Every rental motor vehicle concern subject to this article shall keep such records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers in such form as the finance director and City Clerk may require. (Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-17-12) Sec. 18-74. - Excise tax levied. (a) There is hereby assessed and levied an excise tax upon each rental charge collected by any rental motor vehicle concern when such charge constitutes a taxable event for the purposes of the sales and use tax as provided for under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-1 et seq. on any motor vehicle rental charge made in the city. The tax levied pursuant to this article shall be in the amount of three (3) percent of the rental charge as defined herein. The tax levied pursuant to this article shall be imposed only at the time when and the place where a customer pays sales tax with respect to the rental charge. The customer who pays a rental charge that is subject to the tax levy as provided in this article shall be liable for the tax. The tax shall be paid by the customer to the rental motor vehicle concern. The tax shall be a debt of the customer to the rental motor vehicle concern until it is paid and shall be recoverable at law in the same manner as authorized for the recovery for other debts. The rental motor vehicle concern collecting the tax shall remit the tax to the city, and the tax thus remitted shall be a credit against the tax imposed by this article on the rental motor vehicle concern. Every rental motor vehicle concern subject to the tax levied by this article shall be liable for the tax at the rate of three (3) percent upon the rental charges actually collected or the amount of taxes collected from the customers, whichever is greater. The council declares that the proceeds received from the excise tax levied by this article are to be used for promoting industry, trade, commerce and tourism; capital outlay projects consisting of the construction of convention, trade, sports and recreational facilities, or public safety facilities, including the acquiring, constructing, renovating, improving and equipping of parking facilities, pedestrian walkways, plazas, connections and other public improvements associated with such convention, trade, sports and recreational facilities or public safety facilities or the retirement of debt issued with respect to such capital outlay projects; and maintenance and operation expenses or security and public safety expenses associated with capital outlay projects as mentioned above within the territorial city limits. (Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-17-12) Sec. 18-75. - Exceptions. No tax shall be imposed pursuant to this article on the rental charge associated with the rental or lease of a rental motor vehicle if either: (1) The customer picks up the rental motor vehicle outside the state and returns it within the state; or (2) The customer picks up the rental motor vehicle in the state and returns it outside the state. (Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-17-12) Sec. 18-76. - Amount of tax allowed to be retained for expenses. Each rental motor vehicle concern collecting the tax imposed by this article shall be allowed to retain three (3) percent of the tax due and collected and may retain that amount in the form of a deduction for expenses incurred in submitting, reporting and paying the amount of taxes due, if the amounts due are not delinquent at the time of payment. (Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-17-12) Sec. 18-77. - Statement required showing gross rental charges and taxes. (a) On or before the twentieth day of each month, the motor vehicle concern liable for the tax provided for herein shall transmit to the city a statement showing the gross rental charges and gross taxes collected through authority of this article for each preceding calendar month. Along with said statement, the motor vehicle concern shall submit the net taxes due for each particular month along with a remittance form prescribed by the City Clerk. (b) Failure to remit taxes by the due date shall subject the rental motor vehicle concern to a penalty of five (5) percent of the tax then due and, in addition to such penalty, interest thereon the unpaid principal amount due, computed at the rate of one (1) percent per month or fraction thereof from the due date of the taxes. (Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-17-12) Sec. 18-78. - Records. In order to aid in the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article and collect all the tax imposed, all rental motor vehicle concerns are hereby required to keep a record of rental charges for rental motor vehicles and taxes collected which are related thereto. Said records shall be open for inspection and copying by the City Clerk, or designee, during business hours. (Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-17-12) Sec. 18-79. - Deficiency determinations. (a) If the City Clerk is not satisfied with the return or returns of the excise tax provided for herein, or the amount of the tax required to be paid to the city by any rental vehicle concern, he may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon use of any information within his possession or that may come into his possession. Deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one (1) or more monthly periods. (b) The amount of the determination made by the City Clerk shall bear interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month or fraction thereof from the due date of the taxes found due by him. (c) The City Clerk shall give to the rental vehicle concern a written notice of any such determination. The notice may be made personally or by mail and, if by mail service, shall be addressed to the operator of the rental motor vehicle concern at the address as the same appears in the records of the City Clerk as provided by each rental motor vehicle concern. Service shall be complete when delivered by certified mail with a receipt signed by an addressee or agent of addressee. (d) Except in cases of failure to make a return, every notice of deficiency determination shall be mailed within three (3) years after the twentieth day of the calendar month following the period in which the amount proposed to be determined or within three (3) years after the return was filed, whichever period shall expire last. (Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-17-12) Sec. 18-80. - Audit authority. Duly authorized representatives of the city, upon exhibition of identification and during regular business hours, may examine and copy the books, papers, records, financial reports equipment and other facilities if necessary of any rental motor vehicle concern in order to verify the accuracy of any return made pursuant to this article, or if no return is made by the rental motor vehicle concern, to ascertain or determine the amount of tax required to be paid. (Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-17-12) Sec. 18-81. - Withholding tax on sale of business. (a) If any rental motor vehicle concern liable for any amount under this article transfers or sells its business or quits the business, its successors or assigns shall withhold sufficient amounts from the purchase price to cover the amount required to be paid pursuant to this article until the former owner or operator of the rental motor vehicle concern produces a receipt from the City Clerk or his designee showing that the indebtedness has been paid or a certificate stating that no amount is due. (b) If the purchaser of a business or rental motor vehicle concern fails to withhold from the purchase price as required herein, such purchaser shall be personally liable for the payment of the amount of the outstanding tax required to be withheld by him to the extent of such purchase price. (Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-17-12) Secs. 18-82—18-99. - Reserved.

div.head: Chapter 19 - TRAFFIC AND MOTOR VEHICLES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 3; municipal court, ch. 9; streets and sidewalks, ch. 17; vehicles for hire, ch. 22. State Law reference— Authority to provide devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3(a)(4); Uniform Rules of the Road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; power of local authorities generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371; adoption of uniform rules of the road by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-372; prosecution of traffic offenses, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 19-1. - Definitions. The following words and phrases when used in this chapter shall for the purpose of this chapter have the following meanings: Authorized emergency vehicle means vehicles of the fire department, fire patrol and police department, ambulances and such emergency vehicles of municipal, state and federal departments and of public service corporations as are designated by the City Council. Bicycle means every device propelled by human power upon which any person may ride, having two (2) tandem wheels either of which is over twenty (20) inches in diameter, and including any device generally recognized as a bicycle though equipped with two (2) front or two (2) rear wheels. Business district means any street length between intersections where fifty (50) percent or more of the frontage is in use for business purposes, or where so designated as such by ordinance. Central traffic district means all streets and portions of streets within the area so designated as such by ordinance. Crosswalk means that portion of a roadway ordinarily included within the prolongation or connection of curb and property lines at intersections, or any portion of a roadway clearly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. Curb loading zone means a space adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or materials. Driver or operator means every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a vehicle. Freight curb loading zone means a space adjacent to a curb for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of freight or passengers. Intersection means the area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curb lines, or if none, then of the lateral boundary lines of two (2) or more streets or highways which join one (1) another at an angle, whether or not one (1) such street or highway crosses the other. Laned roadway means a roadway which is divided into two (2) or more clearly marked lanes for vehicular traffic. Limited access highway means every highway, street or roadway in respect to which owners or occupants of abutting property or lands and other persons have no legal right of access to or from the same, except at such points only and in such manner as may be determined by the public authority having jurisdiction over such highway, street or roadway. Motor vehicle means every vehicle which is self-propelled and every vehicle which is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead trolley wires, but not operated upon rails. Motorcycle means every motor vehicle having a saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor. Official time standard, whenever certain hours are named herein, means standard time as may be in current use in this City. Official traffic control devices means all signs, signals, markings and devices not inconsistent with this chapter placed or erected by authority of the City Council, for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic. Park, when prohibited, means the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers. Passenger curb loading zone means a place adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers. Pedestrian means any person afoot, or in a hand-wheeled vehicle. Police officer means every officer of the police department or any officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic or to make arrests for violations of traffic regulations. Private road or driveway means every way or place in private ownership and used for vehicular travel by the owner and those having express or implied permission from the owner, but not by other persons. Railroad means a carrier of persons or property upon cars, other than streetcars, operated upon stationary rails. Residence district means any street length between street intersections where more than fifty (50) percent of the frontage is in use for residence purposes, or where so designated as such by ordinance. Right-of-way means the privilege of the immediate use of the roadway. Roadway means that portion of a street or highway improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel. In the event a highway uses two (2) or more separate roadways, the term "roadway" as used herein shall refer to any such roadway separately but not to all such roadways collectively. Safety zone means the area or space officially set apart within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians and which is protected or is so marked or indicated by adequate signs as to be plainly visible at all times while set apart as a safety zone. Sidewalk means that portion of a street between the curblines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians. Slow means a speed not in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour. Stop, when required, means complete cessation of movement. Stop, stopping or standing, when prohibited, means any stopping or standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control sign or signal. Street or highway means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular traffic. Through highway means every street or highway or portion thereof at the entrances to which vehicular traffic from intersecting streets or highways is required by law to stop before entering or crossing the same and when stop signs are erected as provided in this chapter. Traffic means pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles and other conveyances either singly or together while using any street for purposes of travel. Traffic control signal means any device, whether manually, electrically or mechanically operated, by which traffic is directed. Traffic division means the police department of this City or that portion thereof which may be so designated by ordinance. Trailer means every vehicle without motive power designed for carrying persons or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle. Truck means any vehicle designed and used principally for carrying things other than passengers and having a state truck license. Vehicle means every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, except devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. (Code 1969, § 17-1) Sec. 19-2. - Designation of traffic control areas. The City Council may by a majority vote at any regular or special meeting, by Resolution: (1) Determine and designate one-way streets and no parking areas. (2) Establish traffic control devices or designations and designate and maintain automated red light enforcement devices. (3) Establish through streets. (4) Determine and designate intersections where particular hazards exist. (5) Determine whether motor vehicles shall stop on one (1) or more streets at any stop intersection. A stop sign shall be erected at every such place where a stop is required. (Code 1969, § 17-2; Ord. No. 04-20, § 1, 9-20-04) State Law reference— Powers of local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371. Sec. 19-3. - Abatement of unsafe vehicles as nuisances. (a) The use of any vehicle on the streets is a nuisance where, by reason of a defect in such vehicle, the driving thereof on the streets constitutes a menace or a hazard to the life, safety or property of others. The police department and the members thereof are charged with the duty of enforcing this section. (b) Where it is shown that any vehicle on the street is dangerous or likely to cause injury to persons or property, the police shall cause notice to be given to the owner or other person to remove such vehicle from the streets or, if the vehicle can be made safe by repair, to repair it. In the event such person refuses to obey such a notice, a summons shall be issued requiring him to be and appear in the municipal court to show cause why such vehicle should not be declared a nuisance and abated. (c) If on the hearing the municipal court judge finds from the evidence that such vehicle is a nuisance within the meaning of this section, he shall enter an order so declaring and stating the terms of the abatement and the conditions on which such vehicle may be driven upon the streets. (Code 1969, § 17-3) Sec. 19-4. - Vehicles damaging streets prohibited. No vehicle shall be operated on the streets with cleated wheels, or so constructed in any other way as to damage the street. (Code 1969, § 17-4) Sec. 19-5. - Projecting loads. No vehicle shall be allowed the use of the streets with a load projecting more than four (4) feet in the rear of the body of such vehicle or more than one (1) foot to either side of the vehicle, unless such load has a red flag at least twelve (12) inches square attached to the extreme ends of such projecting load during the daylight hours, and illuminated red light or lantern securely attached to the projecting load during the night hours. (Code 1969, § 17-5) Sec. 19-6. - Play streets designated. The Council may designate by resolution any street or part thereof a play street and place appropriate signs or devices in the roadway indicating and helping to protect the same. (Code 1969, § 17-6) Sec. 19-7. - Use of coasters, roller skates and similar devices restricted. (a) No person upon roller skates, skateboards or other similar nonmotorized toys, or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle, or similar device, shall go upon any roadway except while crossing a street on a crosswalk and when so coasting such person shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. This section shall not apply upon any street while set aside as a play street as authorized by ordinance of this City. (b) It shall be unlawful for persons so skating or riding to gather in crowds or to create noise or be guilty of any disorderly conduct, or to take hold of or hang on to any automobile or other vehicle, or in any way to interfere with the natural progress of automobiles or other vehicles along and in the streets of the City, or for two (2) or more persons to join hands while skating on the sidewalks. Any persons so skating or riding shall give right-of-way to, and in no way interfere with, persons walking on the sidewalks. (c) Any persons violating any provisions of this section shall be subject to the penalties herein provided for violation of this Code. Provided, however, that any such offender under the age of sixteen (16) years shall be dealt with as provided by the state law creating juvenile courts as contained in O.C.G.A. § 15-11-1 et seq. The parent of any child and the guardian of the person of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this section. (Code 1969, § 17-7) Sec. 19-8. - Driving on play streets. Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating any street or part thereof as a play street, no person shall drive a vehicle upon any such street or portion thereof except drivers of vehicles having business or whose residences are within such closed area, and then any such driver shall exercise the highest degree of care in driving upon any such street or portion thereof, and at no time shall such driver's speed exceed five (5) miles per hour. (Code 1969, § 17-43) Sec. 19-9. - Obedience to police. No person shall willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order, signal or direction of a police officer. (Code 1969, § 17-15) State Law reference— Obedience to authorized person directing traffic, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-2. Sec. 19-10. - Public employees to obey traffic regulations. The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the driver of any vehicle owned by or used in the service of the United States government, any state, county or City. It shall be unlawful for any such driver to violate any of the provisions of this chapter except as otherwise permitted in this chapter or by state statute. (Code 1969, § 17-17) Sec. 19-11. - Exemptions for authorized emergency vehicles. (a) The provisions of this chapter regulating the operation, parking, and standing of vehicles shall apply to authorized emergency vehicles. A driver when operating any such vehicle in an emergency, except when otherwise directed by a police officer, may: (1) Park or stand notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter. (2) Proceed past a red or stop signal or stop sign but only after slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation. (3) Exceed the speed limits so long as he does not endanger life or property. (4) Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in specified directions so long as he does not endanger life or property. (b) Those exemptions hereinbefore granted in reference to the movement of an authorized emergency vehicle shall apply only when the driver of such vehicle sounds a horn, siren, bell or exhaust whistle as may be reasonably necessary, and the vehicle displays a lighted red lamp visible as provided in this chapter from the front as a warning to others. (c) The foregoing exemptions shall not, however, protect the driver of any such vehicle from the consequences of his reckless disregard of the safety of others. (Code 1969, § 17-18) Sec. 19-12. - Truck restriction zones. (a) It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any person to operate a truck or commercial vehicle over eighteen (18) tons gross weight or thirty (30) feet in length upon Chestnut Drive, Oakcliff Road, Stewart Road, Park Avenue, Central Avenue, Shallowford Road from Buford Highway north of its intersection with New Peachtree Road and Tilly Mill Road from Flowers Road to Woodwin Road at any time, and on Woodwin Road from 6:30 a.m. to 8:30 a.m. and 1:30 p.m. to 4:30 p.m. Truck traffic shall be permitted from the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. on the following streets: Winters Chapel Road from the intersection of Woodwin Road northerly to the City limits line, except that such vehicles may be operated thereon for the purpose of delivering or picking up materials or merchandise, and then only entering such street at the intersection nearest the destination of the vehicle and proceeding thereon no further than the nearest intersection thereafter. (b) The City shall cause signs to be erected at sufficient distances from the above-referenced truck restriction zones to alert motorists of the zone so that alternate routes can be taken by drivers of the trucks which are prohibited. (Ord. No. 96-4, § 1, 3-18-96; Ord. No. 2014-10, § 1, 10-6-14) Sec. 19-13. - Speed restrictions. The following speed limits for the City are hereby established:
(2) The following speed limits shall be effective upon the following roads and highways:
(Ord. No. 96-18, § 1, 9-3-96; Ord. No. 2012-01, § 2, 1-3-12) Secs. 19-14—19-35. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES
Sec. 19-36. - Uniform rules of the road adopted. (a) Adoption by reference. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-372 through 40-6-376, the Uniform Rules of the Road, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-1 through 40-6-395 as amended from time to time, and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 as amended from time to time are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of this City with like effect as if recited herein. (b) Penalties. Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this article shall be punished in accordance with section 1-12. Sec. 19-37. - Signal to leave parking space. The operator of a parked vehicle, before he starts the vehicle, shall signal his intention to leave the parking space by giving the arm signal for making a left turn. (Code 1969, § 17-36) Sec. 19-38. - Towing. No vehicle shall tow more than one (1) other vehicle, nor shall the connection between vehicles exceed sixteen (16) feet in length. (Code 1969, § 17-50) Sec. 19-39. - U-turns. (a) It shall be unlawful for an operator of any motor vehicle to turn such vehicle so as to proceed in an opposite direction, or to make a U-turn, at any interchange or intersection formed by the intersection of U.S. 23, known as Buford Highway, and any entrance or exit way into or out of Treasure Island Department Store and the tract of property upon which it is located in the 5600 block of Buford Highway in the City. (b) The chief of police is authorized and empowered to erect and maintain "No U-Turn" signs at any intersection or interchange described above to advise motorists of the prohibitions of this section. (Ord. No. 190-1, §§ 1, 2, 4-18-77) State Law reference— U-turns, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-121. Secs. 19-40—19-60. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING
Sec. 19-61. - No parking areas and emergency parking. (a) Restricted. It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle on the following streets and highways within the City except for emergency purposes, to wit: Addison Drive; Buford Highway; Central Avenue; Chesnut Drive; Chicopee Drive, north side, a distance of one hundred seventy-four (174) feet east from Chicopee Park; Church Street; Creston Road; Darlington Oak Drive between 3193 and 3205 Darlington Oak Drive; Doral Drive at 4048; Green Oak Drive, northeast side, between 4093 and 4063; Hickory Wood Road, west side, north of the intersection with Redwood Street; Homeland Drive; Honeysuckle Park, driveway to arena; Honeysuckle Park, in front of gates; McClave Drive; McElroy Road from Buford Highway to New Peachtree Road; Moss Oak Drive, southwest side, side of 4109 Windsor Oak Drive; New Peachtree Road; Oakcliff Road; Oakmont Avenue; Oakmont Avenue at 3635; Park Avenue except as designated in front of the City police department; Peachtree Square; Pine Street at 3540; Pine Street at 3548; Pontiac Circle at 2800; Raymond Drive: (1) Along the north side of the street between 2635 Fairlane Drive and the street's dead end into 3330 Chestnut Drive; (2) South side only for the segment of the street directly across from the intersection with Wheeler Drive and extending a linear distance of ten (10) feet as measured from both ends of the existing entrance steps; (3) At 3130, within twenty (20) linear feet of the roadway intersection with both of the outer edges of the two (2) existing driveway curb cuts of the circular driveway adjacent to Raymond Drive; (4) Between, and inclusive of, 3392 and 3518; Redwood Street, north side, a distance of forty-five (45) feet west from the intersection with Hickory Wood Road; Shallowford Road west of Buford Highway; Spanish Oak Drive, west side, 3912 Spanish Oak Drive; Stafford Place; Stewart Road; east side; Tilly Mill Road; Wheeler Drive: • Along the east side of the street between Raymond Drive and Chestnut Drive; • West side, parking prohibited within five (5) feet of a residential mailbox; Windsor Oak Drive, east side, from 4052 through 4100; Windsor Oak Drive, west side, from 4035 through 4061 and from 4091 through 4125; Winters Chapel Road; and A distance of forty-five (45) feet north and twenty (20) feet south from the utility pole located on the west side of Pin Oak Circle at the intersection of Pin Oak Circle and Red Oak Drive; Three (3) signs in front of Yeshiva School. (b) Definition. For the purpose of this section, the term "emergency" means any mechanical or human failure which would make it unsafe for the vehicle or its driver to continue operating the vehicle or stopping to assist a disabled vehicle or person except when having been told to move on by a law enforcement official. (c) The City may designate such other areas in the City as may be deemed necessary for the protection of the public as no parking areas by placing signs within the restricted areas of such streets and roads where it is determined that the same poses a serious threat to vehicular users or pedestrian traffic. In addition, no vehicle shall be allowed to stop; stand or park in areas prohibited in specified places as more specifically set forth in O.C.G.A. § 40-6-203 or other applicable provisions of state law. (d) Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or official traffic-control device, no person shall stand or park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except momentarily to pick up or discharge a passenger or passengers within twenty (20) feet of an intersection. "Intersection" means the area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curb lines, or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of the roadways of two (2) streets which join one another at, or approximately at, right angles, or the area within which vehicles traveling upon different streets joining at any other angle may come in conflict. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to store, retain, or keep in the City inoperative, wrecked or junked automobiles or other motor vehicles for more than seventy-two (72) hours after being directed to remove such vehicle by the City Clerk, the Mayor, or by the City police department or the City marshall. Such notice shall be affixed to the vehicle in the event the owner or the person storing or keeping such vehicle cannot be determined and personally served with the notice. (b) After the seventy-two-hour period has expired, each day in which the inoperative, wrecked, or junked vehicle remains in the City shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense and a violation of this article and the owner of such vehicle shall be issued a citation. (c) The following vehicles shall, prima facie, be deemed inoperative: (1) Any motor vehicle that does not display a valid, current license tag and registration sticker; (2) Any motor vehicle that does not display a current, valid emission control sticker if required; (3) Any vehicle incapable of being driven or operated; (4) Any vehicle not covered by a valid, current insurance policy as required by state law; (5) Any vehicle with the wheels or tires removed; and (6) Any vehicle without a windshield. (d) Any such vehicle not removed as directed by the City within twenty-four (24) hours after a citation has been served shall be subject to removal by the City or its designee, and all costs or charges associated therewith, including storage, shall be payable by the owner thereof and shall become a charge and lien against the vehicle. (e) Any person who has been given seventy-two (72) hours notification that it is unlawful to store, retain, or keep in the City inoperative, wrecked or junked automobiles or other motor vehicles, or parts thereof, or has on the premises any discarded, dismantled, wrecked, scrapped, ruined or junked automobile or other motor vehicle, or parts thereof, which constitute a health hazard or unsightly nuisance shall not be entitled to subsequent seventy-two (72) hours notification before citations may issue or before the same may be removed. (f) Any person who stores or permits to be stored upon property which he owns or upon which he resides, any junked, wrecked, or inoperative vehicle or car, as defined above, for a period of seventy-two (72) hours in any five-day period, shall be in violation of this section and shall be issued a citation. Notice posted on one (1) vehicle or delivered to the owner or occupant of the property upon which the vehicle is stored shall be sufficient notice as to all junked, wrecked, or inoperative vehicles on the premises at the time of the giving of the notice, or which may be brought onto the premises anytime within a sixty-day period following the service or posting of the notice. Upon the expiration of twenty-four (24) hours after a citation has been served, any junked, wrecked, or inoperative vehicle on the premises may be removed as provided for above, and each day thereafter shall constitute a separate and distinct violation of this section. Sec. 19-160. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. In operation means operating in good working condition. Operator shall mean any individual driving and/or in possession of a vehicle. Owner means the registrant of a motor vehicle, except that such term shall not include a motor vehicle rental company when a motor vehicle registered by such company is being operated by another person under a rental agreement with such company. Recorded images means images recorded by a traffic-control signal monitoring device on: (1) (a) Not less than two (2) photographs; (b) Not less than two (2) microphotographs; (c) Not less than two (2) electronic images; or (d) Videotape; and (2) Showing a traffic-control signal displaying a circular red or red arrow signal along with the rear of a motor vehicle apparently operated in disregard or disobedience of such signal and, on at least one (1) image or portion of tape, clearly revealing the number or other identifying designation of the license plate displayed on the motor vehicle. Signature means any manual or facsimile of a persons signature. System location is the approach to an intersection toward which a photographic, video, digital or electronic camera is directed and is in operation. Traffic-control signal monitoring device means a device with one (1) or more motor vehicle sensors working in conjunction with a traffic-control signal to produce recorded images of motor vehicles being operated in disregard or disobedience of a circular red or red arrow signal. (Ord. No. 04-20, § 1, 9-20-04) Sec. 19-161. - Compliance with traffic-control signals. (a) Vehicular traffic facing a steady circular red signal alone shall stop at a clearly marked stop line or, if the there is no crosswalk, before entering the intersection, and shall remain standing until an indication to proceed is shown by a steady circular green signal. (b) Vehicular traffic facing a steady red arrow signal indication shall stop at a clearly marked stop line or, if there is no stop line, before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or, if there is no crosswalk, before entering the intersection, and shall remain standing until an indication to proceed is shown by a steady green arrow signal indication. (c) The driver of a motor vehicle shall be liable for a civil monetary penalty imposed pursuant to this section if such motor vehicle is found, as evidenced by information obtained from a traffic-control signal monitoring device, to have failed to comply with a traffic light signal as designated in subsections (a) and (b) of this section within the City limits. (Ord. No. 04-20, § 1, 9-20-04) Sec. 19-162. - Proof/certificate. (a) Proof that a particular vehicle entered an intersection in violation of subsections 19-161(a) or (b) of this Code, as detected by a traffic-control signal monitoring device, together with proof that the particular vehicle is registered with the Georgia Department of Public Safety (or any other state or local vehicle registration office) in the charged person's name, shall raise the evidentiary presumption and constitute prima facie evidence in any prosecution of a violation of that section that the charged person was the person driving the vehicle depicted in the recorded image. (b) A certificate, sworn to or affirmed by a trained law enforcement officer or a technician employed by the City public safety department, or a copy thereof, based on inspection of recorded images produced by a traffic-control signal monitoring device shall be considered prima facie evidence of the facts contained therein. (c) Consistent with O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20(f)(7), recorded images made for the purpose of this subsection shall not be a public record. (d) The provisions of this section shall not limit law enforcement agencies to the use of traffic-control signal monitoring devices in enforcing O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20(a); and, when there is evidence obtained from another source or sources which constitutes a prima-facie case of a violation of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20(a), such violation may be prosecuted as otherwise provide by law in lieu of, but not in addition to enforcement under this section. (e) Any recorded images detected by a traffic light signal violation monitoring system shall be available for inspection in any proceeding to adjudicate the liability for such violation pursuant to this section. (f) Such presumption may be rebutted if the owner, or lessee of the vehicle files a sworn notarized statement with the clerk of the municipal court prior to the return date established on the citation identifying the name and address of the operator of the vehicle at the time of the alleged violation. Upon review of the notarized statement by the prosecuting attorney for the City of Doraville, a hearing may be set for prosecution of the alleged violation. (g) Such presumption may be rebutted if the owner, or lessee of the vehicle testifies under oath in open court that he or she was not the operator of the vehicle at the time of alleged violation. (h) Such presumption shall be rebutted if a certified copy of a police report, showing that the vehicle had been reported to the police as stolen prior to the time of the alleged violation, is presented, prior to the return date established on the citation issued pursuant to this section, to the court adjudicating the alleged violation. (i) Such presumption shall be rebutted if the recorded image depicts the vehicle passed through the intersection in violation of subsections 19-161 (a) or (b) of this Code as part of a funeral procession. (j) Such presumption shall be rebutted if the recorded image depicts the vehicle passed through the intersection in violation of subsections 19-161 (a) or (b) of this Code in order to avoid impeding the efforts of an emergency vehicle to pass through the intersection. (k) Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, if the recorded image detected by a traffic light signal violation monitoring system depicts the vehicle passed through the intersection in violation of subsections 19-161(a) or (b) of the Doraville City Code is commercially licensed, then the owner of that vehicle shall be sent notice of the date, time and location of the alleged violation with at least two (2) recorded images thereof. Within ten (10) days of the receipt of said notice, the owner of the vehicle shall provide proof to the City of Doraville of the name and address of the driver of the vehicle at the date, time and location of the violation and within the same time period, shall provide the driver of the vehicle with at least two (2) recorded images of the alleged violation. After receipt by the City of Doraville of the proof of the name and address of the driver of the vehicle, the driver of the vehicle shall be prima facie responsible for such violation. Failure of the owner of the vehicle found to be in violation of subsections 19-161(a) or (b) of the Doraville City Code to provide the name and address of the driver at the time of the violation within the period prescribed shall cause the owner to be held responsible as set forth in subsection 19-162(a) of the Municipal Code of the City of Doraville, Georgia. (Ord. No. 04-20, § 1, 9-20-04) Sec. 19-163. - Penalty. (a) Imposition of a penalty pursuant to this section shall not be deemed a criminal conviction as an operator and shall not be made a part of the operating record of the person upon whom such liability is imposed nor shall it be used for insurance purposes in the provision of motor vehicle insurance coverage. The civil monetary penalty imposed by this section for each violation shall be seventy dollars ($70.00) plus applicable surcharges. (b) Failure to respond to any notice of violation by the prescribed date shall be a waiver of the right to contest the violation, and the person cited shall be liable for a civil monetary penalty of seventy dollars ($70.00) plus applicable surcharges, and such penalty shall be considered a judgment and shall carry interest at the legal rate. (Ord. No. 04-20, § 1, 9-20-04) Sec. 19-164. - Citation. (a) A citation for a violation of this section may be executed by the City by sending by first-class mail a copy thereof to the address of the owner, or lessee of the vehicle as shown, in the case of vehicle owners, in the records of the Georgia Department of Public Safety (or any other state vehicle registration office) or, in the case of vehicle lessees or renters, in the records of the lessor. Said citation shall be postmarked not later than ten (10) days after the date of the alleged violation. (b) No proceedings for contempt or arrest shall be instituted for failure to appear on the return date of the citation. (Ord. No. 04-20, § 1, 9-20-04) Sec. 19-165. - Administration. (a) A private entity may enter into an agreement with the City to be compensated for providing the traffic light signal violation monitoring system or equipment, and all related support services, to include consulting, operations and administration. However, only a trained law enforcement officer or a technician employed by the City public safety department may swear to or affirm the certificate required by subsection 19-162(b). (b) No portion of any fine collected through the use of a traffic-control signal monitoring devices may be paid to the manufacturer or vendor. Compensation to the manufacturer or vendor shall be based on the value of such equipment and shall not be based on the number of citations issued or the revenue generated by traffic-control signal monitoring devices. (Ord. No. 04-20, § 1, 9-20-04) Sec. 19-166. - Signage. (a) The City shall erect signs on every highway, which comprises a part of the state highway system at that point on the highway, which intersects the jurisdictional limits of the City. A sign shall be erected also by the City on each public road on the approach to the next traffic-control signal for such road when a traffic-control device is monitoring such next signal for such road. (b) Such signs shall be at least thirty (30) inches by thirty (30) inches in measurement and shall warn motorists that traffic-control signal monitoring devices are being employed. (Ord. No. 04-20, § 1, 9-20-04) Sec. 19-167. - Warning period. Only warning notices and no citations shall be sent during the thirty-day period commencing with each installation of a traffic-control signal-monitoring device. (Ord. No. 04-20, § 1, 9-20-04)

div.head: Chapter 20 - TRAILER CAMPS AND TOURIST COURTS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Businesses and business regulations, ch. 6; fire protection and prevention, ch. 7; parks and recreation, ch. 12; zoning, ch. 23. State Law reference— Tourist courts, O.C.G.A. § 31-28-1 et seq.; limitation of owner's liability for persons entering for recreational purposes, O.C.G.A. § 51-3-20 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 20-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Permanent trailer means any trailer from which the wheels have been removed except for temporary purposes or repair, and which is attached to the ground by means of posts, piers or a foundation of any type. Trailer means any vehicle, house car, motor home, fifth wheel, movable structure or any portable or movable vehicle on wheels, skids, rollers or blocks, either self-propelled or propelled by any other means, which is designed to be used for residential living, sleeping, commercial or utility purposes. (Code 1969, § 18-1) Sec. 20-2. - Temporary construction trailer. A temporary construction trailer may be used while a permanent structure is being built provided a permit has been issued by the building official, but for not more than ninety (90) days unless the permit is extended. For purposes of this section, a temporary construction trailer means a movable structure located at a construction site wherein the various phases and operations of a construction project are coordinated and administered. Secs. 20-3—20-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TRAILER CAMPS
Sec. 20-26. - General requirements. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to place or maintain any trailer used for human habitation or to use any trailer for living, sleeping or business purposes on any premises in the City. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to park, for use or occupancy, any trailer overnight on any street, alley, highway or other public place. (c) One (1) trailer owned by the holder of fee simple title to the land or the occupant may be parked or stored on any lot or plot, provided that no living quarters shall be maintained nor any business conducted therein while such trailer is so parked or stored. (Code 1969, § 18-19) Sec. 20-27. - Required lot area. (a) No trailer camp shall be constructed or maintained on a lot which has an average width of less than two hundred (200) feet or total area of less than sixty thousand (60,000) square feet. (b) Each trailer space shall be at least twenty-five (25) feet in width and shall provide a minimum of one thousand (1,000) square feet in area exclusive of access driveways, off-street parking and other required service areas; provided, that existing trailer spaces not less than eight hundred (800) square feet may be accepted. (c) Each trailer space shall be defined by a marker at each corner. (Code 1969, § 18-20) Sec. 20-28. - Yard requirements. No trailer shall be located within: (1) Five (5) feet of its individual lot line. (2) Fifteen (15) feet of another such unit side-by-side or end-to-end. (3) Fifty (50) feet of the right-of-way line of any public street or way. (4) Twenty (20) feet of any exterior boundary, excepting any public street or way, of the trailer court. (Code 1969, § 18-21) Sec. 20-29. - Automobile parking requirements. (a) One (1) off-street automobile parking space for each trailer space shall be provided in a trailer camp. (b) Such off-street parking area shall be situated in a location convenient to the occupants of the trailers and shall have ingress and egress by means of a public way. Such off-street parking area shall be paved in accordance with specifications of the public works department of the county. (c) Ingress and egress to parking areas adjacent to a public street shall be through driveways or openings not exceeding twenty-five (25) feet in width in the curb line of the street. (d) Automobile parking shall be prohibited within a trailer camp except in the specified off-street parking areas. (e) Each trailer space shall abut upon a driveway of not less than twenty (20) feet in width. Such driveways shall be of all-weather type, well defined, lighted at night, and shall have clear access to a public thoroughfare. (Code 1969, § 18-22) Sec. 20-30. - Minimum facilities. Each trailer camp shall provide the following minimum facilities on the site for the common use of all trailer occupants: (1) Walkways. Well marked serviceable walkways from each trailer space to toilets, laundry, or other service buildings. (2) Electric outlets. A weatherproof electric outlet supplying one hundred ten (110) volts shall be provided at each trailer space. Power lines over the trailer camp shall be not less than fifteen (15) feet above the ground or in acceptable underground conduits, and no power line shall be permitted to lie on the ground. (3) Refuse collection facilities. One (1) refuse collection station shall be provided for each twelve (12) families or fraction thereof, conveniently located to serve tenants, not more than one hundred (100) feet from any trailer served and shall be conveniently located for collection. Such station shall be constructed with a concrete floor, protected with a roof, properly screened, have a water supply, and shall have sanitary drainage facilities. (4) Water and sewerage. Each trailer shall be connected with water and sanitary facilities in a manner approved by the county health department and in compliance with the plumbing code of the county. (5) Laundry facilities. Laundry facilities shall be connected to approved sanitary facilities and shall be provided at the rate of four (4) laundry trays, two (2) washing machines, and eight (8) ironing boards for each fifty (50) trailer units or fraction thereof. Such facilities shall be located not more than three hundred fifty (350) feet from the trailer units served. (6) Laundry drying yards. Each trailer camp shall provide a fenced laundry drying yard adjacent to laundry facilities. Such drying yards shall provide an aggregate of fifteen (15) feet of clothesline per trailer unit. In lieu of a fenced laundry yard automatic drying equipment consisting of one (1) dryer unit for each ten (10) trailer units or fraction thereof may be substituted. (7) Public telephones. Public telephones shall be provided at convenient locations in separate structures or booths in the proportion of one (1) phone per thirty-five (35) trailer units or fraction thereof. (8) Toilet and bathing facilities. Separate and plainly marked central toilet facilities for each sex shall be provided within two hundred (200) feet of trailer units without private or connecting baths. a. Central facilities shall provide as a minimum: 1. For men: One (1) commode, one (1) lavatory, one (1) urinal, and one (1) tub or showerhead for each ten (10) trailer units or fraction thereof. 2. For women: One (1) commode, one (1) lavatory, one (1) tub, and one (1) showerhead for each ten (10) trailer units, or fraction thereof. b. Sufficient artificial light shall be provided to illuminate adequately each central toilet or bathing facility. (9) Fuel storage. Individual containers and outdoor storage facilities for liquid cooking and heating fuel shall be provided for each trailer unit. Bulk liquid fuel containers shall be provided when necessary to comply with regulations set forth by the fire department of the county. Such containers shall be located conveniently for delivery by fuel trucks. (10) Fire protection. Each trailer unit shall be equipped with a fire extinguisher approved by the fire department of the county. In addition, each trailer camp shall furnish one (1) hose cabinet connected with the county water supply together with fire hose and nozzle, for each twenty-five (25) trailer units or fraction thereof. (11) Landscaping. Each trailer camp shall be landscaped with shade trees and exterior screen planting to provide and assure the reasonable amenities of living and privacy characteristic of more permanent living quarters. (Code 1969, § 18-23) Sec. 20-31. - Improvements to trailers. (a) No permanent additions of any kind shall be built onto or become a part of any transient trailer unit. (b) Permanent additions may be constructed upon, adjacent to, or over permanent trailer units; provided that a building permit is obtained for such additions and that the additions comply with the building, electrical, and plumbing codes and other applicable ordinances; and further provided that no addition encroaches upon the required open spaces as required herein. (Code 1969, § 18-24) Secs. 20-32—20-50. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - TOURIST COURTS
Sec. 20-51. - General requirements. It shall be unlawful for any person to place or maintain a tourist court as herein defined on any premises in the incorporated area of the City except in a commercial or industrial district, and then only when duly permitted and maintained pursuant to the provisions of this article. (Code 1969, § 18-35) Sec. 20-52. - Required lot area. (a) No tourist court shall be constructed or maintained on a lot which has an average width of less than two hundred (200) feet or total area of less than sixty thousand (60,000) square feet. (b) The minimum aggregate gross land area requirement per sleeping unit shall be one thousand (1,000) square feet. (c) The minimum area of premises used or occupied as a living unit shall be one hundred seventy (170) square feet. Each structure shall contain not less than two (2) units. (Code 1969, § 18-36) Sec. 20-53. - Yard requirements. No building shall be located within: (1) Twenty (20) feet from any sideline. (2) Ten (10) feet from any other structure. (3) Twenty-five (25) feet of the rear lot line. (4) One hundred twenty (120) feet from the centerline of any public county road or any state highway situated within the City or any other highway which may be designated as an arterial highway and in no instance less than forty-five (45) feet from the property line abutting such public road or highway. (5) Seventy-five (75) feet from the centerline of any minor street and in no instance less than forty-five (45) feet from the property line abutting such public road or highway. (Code 1969, § 18-37) Sec. 20-54. - Automobile parking requirements. (a) One (1) off-street automobile parking space for each living unit shall be provided in a tourist court. (b) Such off-street parking area shall be situated in a location convenient to the occupants of the living units and shall have ingress and egress by means of a public way. Such off-street parking area shall be paved in accordance with specifications of the public works department of the county. (c) Ingress and egress to parking areas adjacent to a public street shall be through driveways or openings not exceeding twenty-five (25) feet in width in the curbline of such street. (d) Automobile parking shall be prohibited within a tourist court except in the specified off-street parking areas. (Code 1969, § 18-38) Sec. 20-55. - Minimum facilities. Each tourist court shall provide the following minimum facilities on the site for the common use of all occupants: (1) Water and sewerage. All plumbing in the tourist camps shall be connected with water and sanitary facilities in a manner approved by the county health department in compliance with the plumbing code of the county. (2) Public telephone. As specified for trailer camps. (3) Toilet and bathing facilities. Each unit shall have a lavatory, commode and shower or tub, and shall be supplied with hot and cold running water. (4) Fire protection. Each tourist camp shall furnish one (1) fire hose cabinet connected with the county water supply, together with fire hose and nozzle, for each twenty-five (25) units or fraction thereof and any other facilities required by the county fire department. (5) Landscaping. As specified for trailer camps. (Code 1969, § 18-39)

div.head: Chapter 21 - UTILITIES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Special assessments, § 4.06. Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 5; franchise agreements, § 6-236 et seq.; floodplain regulations, ch. 8; pollution control, ch. 13; soil erosion and sedimentation control, ch. 16; streets and sidewalks, ch. 17; zoning, ch. 23. State Law reference— Power of City or county to provide stormwater, sewerage collection and disposal systems, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3.; dumping certain wastes in storm or sanitary sewers prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-2; Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; adoption of ordinances, rules and regulations relating to payment for street improvements and construction of water, gas and sewer connections, payment of costs of connections, O.C.G.A. § 36-39-7; City's authority to acquire, construct, extend, operate, maintain and collect fees for water and sewerage systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-5; Resource Recovery Development Authorities Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-63-1 et seq.; grants of state funds to municipal corporations for public purposes, O.C.G.A. § 36-40-20 et seq.; executions for collection of assessments for laying sewers, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-358.
Sec. 21-1. - Incorporation of lines into county system; jurisdiction of county. The City Council does hereby consent and agree that the sewer lines of the City shall be incorporated within the county sewerage system and that thereafter the sewer department of the county shall have jurisdiction over all such sewer lines. (Code 1969, § 14-1) Sec. 21-2. - Maintenance, repair, extension by county; authority to open streets. The county shall have authority to maintain all existing sewer lines and any additions or any extensions which may be made thereto, and the county is further authorized and empowered to open any public streets or alleys within the territorial limits of the City for the purpose of repairing, maintaining, constructing, or extending any such sewer lines, provided, however, that the county shall complete maintenance or construction with as little inconvenience to the citizens of the City as is practical and possible. Upon the completion of such maintenance and construction, the streets or alleys which may be opened shall be closed and repaired in as good condition as the same were in prior to such maintenance or construction. (Code 1969, § 14-2) Sec. 21-3. - Assessment of costs of construction. The county shall have the full power and authority to levy and assess the cost of construction or extending any sewer lines against the abutting property owners in accordance with the Act of the General Assembly approved February 25, 1949, (1949 Ga. Laws, page 1590), and shall also have the authority and right to collect any and all charges, service fees and costs which are provided for in such Act; provided, however, that any such assessment, service fees, charges, or taxes levied against the citizens of the City shall be upon the same basis and not in excess of such charges levied elsewhere in the county sewerage system. (Code 1969, § 14-3)

div.head: Chapter 22 - TAXICABS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 2015-09 , § 1, adopted July 6, 2015, changed the title of Ch. 22 from "Vehicles for Hire" to read as herein set out. Cross reference— Businesses and business regulations, ch. 6; traffic and motor vehicles, ch. 19; zoning, ch. 23. State Law reference— Reciprocal agreements as to operation of vehicles registered in other states inapplicable to motor vehicles for hire, O.C.G.A. § 40-2-95.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 22-1. - Definitions. For the purposes of this chapter, certain terms and words are hereby defined. Where words are not herein defined, but are defined in sections of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Doraville, those words shall have the meaning as defined therein. As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following words and terms shall have the meaning ascribed to them: City shall mean that area located within the corporate limits of the City of Doraville as amended from time to time. Open stand shall mean locations on the streets of the City, including the locations on the premises of MARTA stations that may be used by any taxicab on a nonexclusive, first come, first served basis, and not by private vehicles or other public conveyances. Taxicab shall mean a motor vehicle used to transport passengers for a fee or fare and which is fitted with a taximeter or other device that is used to compute such fee or fare. Taxicab company shall mean an entity licensed to do business by the State of Georgia with its primary business being the operation of motor vehicles used to transport passengers for a fee or fare and operating within the City. Taximeter shall mean an instrument or device attached to a motor vehicle and designed to measure the distance traveled by such vehicle, or an instrument or device attached to a motor vehicle and designed to compute and indicate the fare or fee to be charged to the passenger(s). (Ord. No. 04-22, § 1(2), 10-18-04; Ord. No. 2015-09 , § 1, 7-6-15) Sec. 22-2. - Doing business defined. Any person or company shall be deemed doing business in the City under this chapter if such person is picking up passengers in the City and accepting or soliciting any consideration, charge or fee which is determined by agreement, by mileage, or by the length of time the taxicab is used. Any person shall also be deemed as doing business in the City under this chapter if such person has established a business relationship with independent contractors or operates taxicab(s) on such person's own behalf for the purpose of transporting passengers in the City. (Ord. No. 04-22, § 1(2), 10-18-04; Ord. No. 2015-09 , § 1, 7-6-15) Sec. 22-3. - Compliance. No person shall conduct the business of operating taxicabs in the City without first meeting the requirements of this chapter. (Ord. No. 04-22, § 1(2), 10-18-04; Ord. No. 2015-09 , § 1, 7-6-15) Sec. 22-4. - Taxicab company permit holder's responsibilities for violations. Taxicab company permit holders are responsible for violations of this chapter by their employees and independent contractors, including company drivers and dispatchers. (Ord. No. 04-22, § 1(2), 10-18-04) Sec. 22-5. - Notice. For the purposes of this chapter, notice shall be deemed delivered when personally served or when served by mail within three (3) days after the date of deposit in the United States mail. (Ord. No. 04-22, § 1(2), 10-18-04) Sec. 22-6. - Appeals of administrative decisions. Decisions of the City Manager that adversely affect or aggrieve any applicant or licensee may be appealed to a Hearing Officer in accordance with section 1-15(b) of this Code. (Ord. No. 04-22, § 1(2), 10-18-04; Ord. No. 2015-09 , § 1, 7-6-15) Editor's note— Ord. No. 2015-09 , § 1, adopted July 6, 2015, changed the title of § 22-6 from "Hearings" to read as herein set out. Sec. 22-7. - Audits; filing returns. Each company and individual licensed under the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to the provisions of Article XII of Chapter 6 for audits and the filing of returns. No licensed business or individual shall fail to comply with the audit requirements of the City. (Ord. No. 04-22, § 1(2), 10-18-04; Ord. No. 2015-09 , § 1, 7-6-15) Sec. 22-8. - Taxicab company permits; generally. (a) An applicant for a taxicab company permit is required to provide information showing its qualifications on a form(s) provided by the City. (b) Applicants must be approved by the City Manager or designee, and such clearance shall include a background investigation. (c) No taxicab company permit shall be issued to any taxicab company owning or leasing less than one (1) vehicle. (d) No taxicab company permit shall be issued to an applicant unless the applicant has a valid and current occupation tax certificate to do business in the City if an occupation tax certificate is required by this Code. (e) The taxicab company permit shall expire at the end of one (1) year from the date of issue and must be renewed prior to that date. (f) If the applicant is not a sole proprietor or individual, then all partners, officers, shareholders, directors, members, managers holding ten (10) percent or more interest in the company or entity shall be required to comply with the provisions of this section. (g) All applicants must: (1) Be at least twenty-one (21) years of age; (2) Be a citizen of the United States or an alien admitted for permanent residence or who has otherwise been granted employment authorization by the United States Department of Homeland Security (DHS); (3) Have not been convicted, pled guilty or Nolo Contendere, been on probation, parole, or been imprisoned for a period of five (5) years previous to the date of application, for the violation of any of the following offenses of the State of Georgia, of any other state, or of the United States: any felony; driving under the influence of drugs or alcohol; criminal solicitation to commit any of the offenses listed in this subsection; attempt to commit any of the offenses listed in this subsection; any misdemeanor crime of violence or theft; any misdemeanor crime of possession, sale or distribution of illegal drugs; or any crime involving moral turpitude. Discharge without court adjudication of guilt pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 42-8-62 shall not disqualify an applicant from applying for a permit; (4) Provide a verifiable dispatch location staffed by company agents or employees, have a published telephone number and have sufficient parking to accommodate its taxicabs when not in use; (5) Provide proof that the applicant has a dedicated two-way communication system with a dispatcher that personally mans such communication system during the entire time that the applicant's business is open for service, or that any taxicab is available for transportation of fee-paying passengers. The dedicated two-way communication system must be a Federal Communications Commission licensed two-way radio network. Citizens Band radios, ham radios, cell phones and text paging devices shall not qualify as a dedicated two-way communication system; (6) File applications for the initial permitting and inspection of the taxicabs, with a list of all drivers that will be scheduled for driver permitting, indicating whether drivers are company employees or contract drivers. A copy of each contract driver's insurance coverage must be included in the application; (7) Provide a copy of the applicant's rate schedule and the daily hours of operation; and (8) Provide the name, address and telephone number of a responsible individual residing in DeKalb County who will be the registered agent for the purpose of service of process or receipt of citations. (9) Companies are responsible for reporting any change in qualifications or other licensing or permitting information previously supplied to the City within ten (10) days of the change. (Ord. No. 04-22, § 1(2), 10-18-04; Ord. No. 07-09, § 1, 12-5-07; Ord. No. 2015-09 , § 1, 7-6-15) Sec. 22-9. - Insurance. (a) All companies and drivers permitted pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall provide with their application, and shall maintain for the duration of the permit, a certificate of insurance showing proof of motor vehicle insurance covering public liability and property damage issued by a state approved insurer. Such insurance shall insure passengers and third persons against personal injury and property damage in amounts specified by this section. (b) All companies and drivers permitted pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall provide with their application, and shall maintain for the duration of the permit, a liability insurance policy issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in this state, which provides the following minimum coverage: $100,000 - For injury to or death of one (1) person in one (1) accident; $300,000 - For injury to or death of two (2) or more persons in any one (1) accident; and $1,000,000 - For injury to or destruction of property of others in any one (1) accident. (c) All permit holders must provide the City with an annual certificate of insurance showing the existence of such policies of insurance as required by this chapter. The annual certificate of insurance must be provided thirty (30) days prior to the expiration of any such insurance. (Ord. No. 04-22, § 1(2), 10-18-04; Ord. No. 2015-09 , § 1, 7-6-15) Sec. 22-10. - Taxicab driver's permits; generally. (a) No person shall drive a taxicab without a valid driver's permit issued pursuant to the requirements of this chapter. All drivers must have held a valid Georgia driver's license for a minimum period of one (1) continuous year prior to applying for a driver's permit pursuant to this chapter. No company permitted for operating taxicabs shall employ or associate with in any way, including independent contractors, any driver who has not first met the requirements of this chapter and been issued a valid driver's permit as authorized by this chapter. (b) No drivers' permit shall be issued to any person who is not employed by or represented by a licensed company. All drivers' permits shall expire on the drivers' birthday, and shall be renewed annually. (c) Driver permits must be posted on the dash or sun visor of the vehicle being driven so that it is visible from the passenger area. Licensees under this chapter are responsible for checking to ensure that each driver has a current driver permit in the driver's possession and posted on the dash or sun visor of the vehicle being operated along with a visible vehicle inspection sticker. (d) No request for a driver's permit will be processed unless the permit applicant presents a letter on company stationery to the police department from a licensed company requesting issuance of a driver's permit to the named individual. The driver's permit applicant will further furnish information requested on a form to be provided by the City and submit to a police clearance consisting of a background investigation. Driver permit applicants must meet the following requirements: (1) Be at least twenty-one (21) years of age. (2) Be a citizen of the United States or an alien admitted for permanent residence or who has otherwise been granted employment authorization by the United States Department of Homeland Security. (3) Possess a current valid State of Georgia driver's license. Such license must not be limited as defined in O.C.G.A. §§ 40-5-58 and 40-5-64. (4) Be familiar with the traffic laws and ordinances of the City of Doraville. (5) Exhibit a proficiency with the English language so as to be able to comprehend and interpret traffic signs, issue written receipts to passengers and obey lawful orders of police and others in lawful authority. (6) Have not been convicted, pled guilty or Nolo to, been on probation, parole, or been imprisoned for a period of five (5) years previous to the date of application, or for the violation of any of the following offenses of the State of Georgia, of any other state or of the United States: any felony; driving under the influence of drugs or alcohol; child molestation; criminal solicitation to commit any of the offenses listed in this subsection; attempt to commit any of the offenses listed in this subsection; any crime of violence or theft; any crime of possession, sale or distribution of illegal drugs; or moral turpitude. Discharge without court adjudication of guilt pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 42-8-62 shall not disqualify an applicant. (7) Have not been convicted of four (4) or more moving traffic violations, or one (1) or more mandatory suspensions as defined by Georgia law, within the twenty-four (24) month period preceding the date of application or renewal of the application. Discharge without court adjudication of guilt pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 42-8-62 shall not disqualify an applicant. (e) Drivers are responsible for reporting any change in qualifications or other licensing or permitting information previously supplied to the police department within ten (10) days of the change. (Ord. No. 04-22, § 1(2), 10-18-04; Ord. No. 05-04, § 1, 2-22-05; Ord. No. 2015-09 , § 1, 7-6-15) Sec. 22-11. - Determination of permit or inspection fees; proration of license, permit or inspection fees. Fees for vehicle inspections and driver permits under this chapter shall be recommended by the police department for approval by the City Council. Fees required by this chapter are nonrefundable and are not prorated. (Ord. No. 04-22, § 1(2), 10-18-04) Sec. 22-12. - Transfer and term of permits and vehicle stickers. (a) No company permits, driver's permits, licenses or City inspection stickers for individual vehicles required by this chapter are transferable; and they shall expire annually as provided in this chapter. If not renewed in compliance with this chapter, all such licenses, permits and inspection stickers shall expire annually and be of no further force and effect. (b) All City inspection stickers required by the provisions of this chapter shall expire on the date the Georgia motor vehicle license tag expires. (Ord. No. 04-22, § 1(2), 10-18-04) Sec. 22-13. - Suspension or revocation of permit. (a) For reasons set forth below, a company permit or a driver's permit issued under this chapter may be suspended until these conditions no longer exist: (1) Failure to maintain all of the general qualifications applicable to the initial issuance of a license or driver's permit. (2) Violation of any part of this chapter. (3) For driver's permits only: have not been convicted of, or pled guilty or Nolo to four (4) or more moving traffic violations, or one (1) or more mandatory suspensions as defined by Georgia law, within the twelve-month period preceding the date of application or renewal of the application. Discharge without court adjudication of guilt pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 42-8-62 shall not disqualify an applicant. (4) Allowing the required insurance coverage to lapse, or allowing a vehicle to operate in the City without a City inspection sticker. (b) For reasons set forth below, a company permit or a driver's permit issued under this chapter may be suspended for six (6) to twelve (12) months or revoked: (1) Charging a fare in excess of those fares on file with the police department. (2) Refusing to accept a passenger solely on the basis of race, color, national origin, religious belief, sex or sexual orientation. Sexual orientation shall mean the state of being heterosexual, homosexual or bisexual. (3) The applicant furnished fraudulent or untruthful information or omits requested information in the application; or (4) Any violation of this article. (5) Any reasons otherwise listed in this article for authority to deny a permit. (c) In addition to any other remedies provided by law, the permit holder may also be cited for violating the provisions of this chapter, and such citation(s) shall be prosecuted in accordance with the requirements of the City Code in the Doraville Municipal Court. (d) The requirements of this chapter shall be in addition to all other licensing, taxing, and regulatory provisions of local, state or federal law and shall not authorize violations of any other applicable laws. (Ord. No. 04-22, § 1(2), 10-18-04; Ord. No. 2015-09 , § 1, 7-6-15) Sec. 22-14. - Vehicle condition and equipment; inspection and inspection sticker. (a) Drivers and company licensees are responsible for maintaining each taxicab in a clean and mechanically safe condition. The interior and exterior shall meet the requirements set out under inspection requirements outlined in this section. (b) Drivers are not to drive and company licensees are not to allow drivers to operate a vehicle without the required markings, a taximeter, top light and inspection sticker as outlined in this section. Required markings shall also include the name of the company painted or affixed by decal to the outside right and left front doors and the schedule of rates, including minimum fares, painted or affixed by decal to the outside right and left rear doors.
